ResponsesInList.Title: Extracting Large Logs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi We use Moodle for commercial purposes, and our company is interested in site activity and not just learning activities . We have been using the log to track and analyse login data, guest activity, and more. Unfortunately, our log has grown too large to extract, and I get a " Hmmm... cant reach this site " in my browser every time I try to extract a log. Is there a way or a trick to extract large logs, without the browser giving up? Or Partner does not have any suggestions. Best regards, Lene Marie

ResponsesInList.Title: Extracting Large Logs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lene, You can pull them all directly from the database . It should be in the table mdl_logstore_standard_log. The "mdl_" part of the table name may be different in your instance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Custom Reports-Time Completed Range?
ResponsesInList.Text: I use Customer Reports (4.4+) to pull all course completions for a date range. I expected that course completions from the early hours of this morning (11/17) would be included in the results. However, the Date to criteria never seems to be included in the results. Is that correct?

ResponsesInList.Title: Custom Reports-Time Completed Range?
ResponsesInList.Text: my assumption is that it is looking at midnight the morning of 11/13 through midnight the morning of 11/17 (so 00:00 of the one day through 0:00 of the other day, which essentially is 11:59 on 11/16) -- so I think to include items from the morning of 11/17 you'd actually need to pick 11/18 so it picks up all of 11/17 Edit -- for clarity, my assumption is that the "Date to" means "up to but not including" instead of "up to and including"

ResponsesInList.Title: Custom Reports-Time Completed Range?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shirley, John is indeed accurate in his assessment - the behaviour was " up to but not including ", however we updated this filter behaviour in MDL-85120 to remove ambiguity and add more flexibility with dates/times

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Statistics report processing start time?
ResponsesInList.Text: The documentation for Moodle's Statistics report says: TIP: Set the stats processing to start an hour before your automated course backups are scheduled to start, then set the maximum runtime to 1 hour. This ensures that stats are not being processed at the same time as course backups are being made. However, the settings in Server ¬ª Statistics don't seem to include any settings related to specifying when the statistics processing will run (only how long it will run for and the amount of data to process). Is this something that it is now no longer necessary to set explicitly? (We are running Moodle 4.5)

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Statistics report processing start time?
ResponsesInList.Text: It might be referring to the Cron jobs (Admin - Server - Tasks - Scheduled Tasks): there is a task for "Background processing for statistics (\core\task\stats_cron_task)"?

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Statistics report processing start time?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks - well found! (Although it looks like I won't actually need to change any settings: from the logs accessible via that page it looks as though the statistics report only takes a few seconds to run, so that hopefully rules it out as a potential cause of server load for us.)

Thank you in advance for sharing your experiences and suggestions!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Completion Report settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Are your cron jobs running frequently? Completion marks as started Calculate regular completion data

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Completion Report settings

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Completion Report settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Site admin> Server >Tasks>Scheduled tasks The scheduled tasks (or cron jobs) are displayed as a list. The two I would look at, at listed above. Completion marks as started Calculate regular completion data You can view the last time they were executed, and how frequently they are set to execute. You might allow have the ability to Run Now - Which I use if I make a massive change and want to see how it affects the student's view.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Completion Report settings
ResponsesInList.Text: What I was suggesting was that the Black H5P activities might not trigger the course completions you desire. I do not use the black plugin option, and I don't even use the blue Moodle core option to trigger a completion condition for my courses. You need to evaluate how are these H5P activities different than other H5P activities that work on different courses. There must be something different. Compare what works against that course that doesn't. There is no existing functionality to manual override the course completion for activities that are not manually completed, such as quizzes.

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL issue, tallying with user defined variable
ResponsesInList.Text:
Can anyone explain to me a discrepancy with the output for the SQL statement ‚ÄúUser's accumulative time spent in course‚Äù in ad hoc contributed reports? https://docs.moodle.org/500/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports The prev_time column in the SQL doesn't always give results as expected. The first hundred rows or so look OK, but then it gives me many lines with the same timestamp for timecreated and prev_time (rendering delta to be zero) 
```text
@prevtime := (SELECT max(timecreated) FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log WHERE userid = 1637 and id < l.id ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 1) AS prev_time
```
 I am running mariadb (5.5.5-10.6.16-MariaDB) on Moodle 4.1.19 (Build: 20250609) See attached screenshot. Any help would be appreciated, thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL issue, tallying with user defined variable
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I want to point out that many events in Moodle have identical timestamps, as certain actions are logged as multiple events with the same timestamp. I suspect you might be looking to calculate something like time-on-task. If that's the case, I recommend checking out the work of Daniela Rotelli; she wrote her PhD on this topic and explains when Moodle tends to use the same timestamp for multiple events. So, the SQL statement might be correct, but you may be expecting a different result. If, like me, you're feeling a bit rusty with SQL, you could also try coming up with a solution using LLM.

ResponsesInList.Title: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Referring to this discussion https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=441131 User's accumulative time spent in course Which uses this code https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports?_gl=1*1550key*_ga*MTAzNzQ0MzMzOS4xNzMyMDIwMzg1*_ga_QWYJYEY9P5*MTc0NDAyMzUxMS4yMS4xLjE3NDQwMjM5ODQuMC4wLjA.#User.27s_accumulative_time_spent_in_course Which is working for me. But is there a better, more efficient way to know how much time a student spent in a course if he is only using the Moodle mobile app? I have found that the logs for web based access vs webservices (app) are very different. You might have only one record for clicking on a page of an assignment if you access with a web browser but several api requests if you are doing it by mobile. Is there a native, more efficient way of knowing how much time a certain student has spent with the mobile app open on a certain Moodle course? Best,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: In general, you will never know how much "time" students spend doing anything, even reading the textbook, because you cannot account for "breaks." The mobile app on an iPhone can be opened, but then the student can switch to messaging, answer a phone call, browse the Internet, or many other things. And even if the student opens the Moodle app, leaves it open, but reads a book, how does one calculate time? That query seems to make some assumptions about time, as do other LMSs. I just don't think you can get any accurate picture of "time." This question about "time spent in course" always makes me wonder, "Why?" A student who is a speed reader might read textbook chapter in 30 minutes, whereas the slow reading student takes 2 hours. What does it matter? Your question is asked frequently, so if you do a little more searching, you will find many more discussions about "time on ... (activity, video, LMS, SCORM , etc.)" The Canvas LMS provides a "time in course" statistic. ¬†Lots of folks like it. ¬†However, I explored this in depth with the Canvas data experts and found that they knew, just as I knew, that it is a completely bogus calculation. ¬†It errs on the high side, which makes it seem like students are spending a lot of time in Canvas. ¬†This seems to help sell the Canvas LMS. ¬†But again, it's a bogus statistic.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rick, I agree with you 200%! And I remind also people at my University that you can have your window in the browser open and simply listen to music while watching birds flying outside. But it is a requirement. So with the explicit assumption that counting intervals between clicks in the web-browser equals "time studying". Does the mobile app have an internal native counter that you can query, that measures how much time the app was the one active/maximixed on your phone? (I use Samsung, so I don't know about Iphone, but you can only have one app in the screen at any particular moment, even though they can run in the background. Best,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: A query can be set up to gather how many times a student has accessed Moodle. This begins with the logstore_standard_log table, but then you must join it with a few other tables to get students' names, etc. Then, you get to make your own assumptions about how much time a student spends on your Moodle when they "click in." Let's say, 5 minutes. If you don't like what you see, you can adjust to 5 minutes to any value that you want until you get something that looks good to you. I am unsure if the logstore_standard_log table has some data in it to capture if the click was from a mobile device. Perhaps someone else will know.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: While I agree that each estimate of time-on-task is flawed, I don't consider it to be a meaningless statistic. However, determining accuracy is not straightforward. The simplest approach would be to sum the duration of specific events recorded in the log table, but the situation is more complex than it first appears. The most advanced - at least to my knowledge - estimation of time-on-task using Moodle data is presented in the works of Daniela Rotelli: Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (n.d.). A Data Science Perspective on Online Student Temporal Learning Patterns and Dynamics . Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2021). Making Sense of Moodle Log Data (Version 4). arXiv. https://doi.org/10.48550/ARXIV.2106.11071 Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2022). Time-on-Task Estimation by data-driven Outlier Detection based on Learning Activities . LAK22: 12th International Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference , 336‚Äì346. https://doi.org/10.1145/3506860.3506913 Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2023). Processing and Understanding Moodle Log Data and Their Temporal Dimension. Journal of Learning Analytics , 10 (2), Article 2. https://doi.org/10.18608/jla.2023.7867 Hope this helps. But don't blame me that I sent you down the rabbit hole.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not blaming you for making me look at these articles. I understand how publishing in journals is important to some. I might say, "Rotelli and Monreal have done a good job squeezing four journal articles out of one theme," but so what? The bottom line is that Moodle records clicks, not time. So you don't know. There is no "duration" field in the log table to sum. Consider a Moodle quiz. In the quiz results, Moodle shows when the quiz was started and when it was ended. You might want to calculate that a student spent 32 minutes on a quiz by subtracting start time from end time. But you don't know what the student really did between these two times. Did they take a 10 minute break? Who knows. And you can't even conclude anything about how fast a student finished a quiz. Is the faster student smarter? Or is the student who spent more time on the quiz the smarter student (perhaps because they know not to rush). The quiz results tell you much more than time tells you. I actually once did this analysis, in my "Business Analytics" course. I plotted exam results against time and ended up with no correlation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time spent in course with Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Rick and Jerz.

ResponsesInList.Title: MAX(CASE problem with ad-hoc reporting
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm working on optimising some of our more complex queries and have run into an issue. I have a query which works correctly when used directly through MySQL workbench but results in a 'page not found' when attempting to run through ad-hoc reporting. It works fine until MAX() is wrapped around the CASE statements. Does anyone have any ideas on this? Is it a known featur? Is there a workaround? attached is a simplified version created for testing which again works correctly within MY SQL Workbench Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MAX(CASE problem with ad-hoc reporting
ResponsesInList.Text: Does this work for you? (I don't have access to Workbench to test it...) `SELECT` `mu.username,` `ui.manager,` `ui.Organisation,` `ui.Unit,` `ui.Region,` `ui.Area,` `ui.Branch` `FROM {user} mu` `LEFT JOIN (` `SELECT` `uid.userid,` `MAX(CASE WHEN uif.shortname = 'manager' THEN uid.data END) AS manager,` Or this: `SELECT` `mu.username,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'manager') AS manager,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l3') AS Organisation,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l4') AS Unit,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l5') AS Region,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l6') AS Area,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l7') AS Branch` `FROM {user} mu` `WHERE mu.deleted = 0 AND mu.suspended = 0` `AND mu.username = '20001143'`

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle logs participants filter not showing those not part of a group
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, In a Moodle environment where the course-level group mode is set to 'Visible groups,' participants who haven't been assigned to any group are not appearing in the Participants filter on the Moodle logs screen. However, their activity logs are still displayed when I select to view all logs or when I download the logs report as a CSV file. I'm just wondering if this has always been the case? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle logs participants filter not showing those not part of a group
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, this behavior has been observed in Moodle for some time. When group mode is set to 'Visible groups,' users who aren't assigned to any group often don't appear in the Participants filter on the Moodle logs screen. This is likely by design, as the filter is intended to show only those participants tied to specific groups.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle logs participants filter not showing those not part of a group
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, you say it can be by design but all other drop-down menus in Report/log page select for "all" (the whole) by default. If "All participants" is not really listing all participants but some, this isn't quite consistent and this is confusing for teachers and admin. Otherwise, there is a separate "All group" menu that allow to filter for one group. As a result, participants not belonging to any group (teachers and students) can't be selected to filter logs results when the course is in "visible groups" or "separate group" mode ("no group" is OK). For me, it's an issue. I create one in the tracker : https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-84514 Regards, Marina

ResponsesInList.Title: How to track deletion of Course Modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Lucas! üòä Unfortunately, Moodle does not register module deletions by default, which can be a bit frustrating, especially for those who want a complete history of course changes. However, I have a suggestion for you: this feature, to track deletions, needs to be in the core of Moodle, but you can submit a request to have it implemented directly in MoodleHQ. To do so, simply access the following link: https://tracker.moodle.org/ , and if you don‚Äôt have an account there yet, you‚Äôll need to create one. Once you access it, check if there is already a similar request. If not, you can open a new "Feature Request," explaining that you would like an option to track module deletions, with details of who made the change and when. The clearer your request, the more likely it is to be noticed and possibly implemented in the next version of Moodle. For sure, if everyone contributes suggestions on the tracker, Moodle will become even better! I hope this solution helps you, and if you have any other questions, I‚Äôm here to help! üòä Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Report with Looker Studio
ResponsesInList.Text: Good evening, I hope you are all well. Since I didn‚Äôt find much information in Moodle forums and considering the high price or lack of customization options in plugins to track users in Moodle, I‚Äôll share some of my experience creating a report with Google Looker Studio, connected to my Moodle database . The report is divided into three sections . The first part includes various general data about Moodle, such as the number of users, enrollments, active users, courses by category, the number of completions per course, new registrations, logins by date, and users who haven't logged in. In the second part, I focused on courses. When selecting a course name, it displays the number of users enrolled in the course, the data we want to bring in, and their completion status. It also shows the number of completions, percentage of completions, and percentage of completions by gender (if the user data is available). In the third and final part, I focused on individual users. By selecting a user from the list, it brings up their main data, completion percentage across the courses they are enrolled in, detailed information for each course, and at the end, the number of logins per month for the user. To achieve this, I first took a course on Udemy, I believe, on Looker Studio. It explains the use of each type of graph and its applications. But the most important thing it teaches is how to relate different tables in the database to extract the data. Another important aspect is having significant knowledge and access to our Moodle database to know where to extract the data from and how to relate it to other tables. For example, to create the completion tables, I joined five tables: the user table to get their data and user ID, which connects with the `userid` in `mdl_user_enrolments` and `mdl_enrol` , which in turn connects with `mdl_course` through a common field, and is joined with `mdl_completion` to get the completion status. It‚Äôs not something you can do in half an hour with ChatGPT, but I believe it‚Äôs really worth it, especially for those of us who work with many users and the free plugins don‚Äôt cover all the data we need. These reports can be downloaded directly from Looker Studio, but it also allows you to embed them in Moodle, either as a resource or, as I did, within a static page. I‚Äôm available for any questions you may have. Best regards and sorry about my gpt english!

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I just realized there are no statistics available on our moodle 4.2.1 website. All I get is "Sorry, there is no available data to display" and a link to the docs .¬†This is true for the site statictics ( /report/stats/index.php ) as well as for the individual course statictics ( /report/stats/index.php?course=<id> ). This is what I checked: Statistics have been enabled since yesterday ( enablestats on admin/settings.php?section=optionalsubsystems ). All options are set to default ( statsfirstrun , statsmaxruntime , statsruntimedays , and statsuserthreshold on admin/settings.php?section=stats ). The job "Background processing for statistics" ( \core\task\stats_cron_task ) ran at midnight for 35 seconds (success; 59 reads; 16s writes). I also ran it manually two hours ago from /admin/tool/task/scheduledtasks.php (success; 0 reads; 4 writes) . The docs mention a potential problem with missing files in the moodle/mod folder. I'm not sure what "If you find any, they should be deleted" means exactly. I don't see any messages about missing files in the browser window, however. There are log entries for each course going back several months. The cronjob should generate statistics from these entries, right? Thanks Oliver

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No statistics available
ResponsesInList.Text: Ensure that the required statistics tables in your Moodle database are set up correctly. Sometimes, missing or corrupted tables can lead to this issue. Verify that there‚Äôs enough recent activity in your courses to generate meaningful statistics. Since you mentioned months of log entries, there should be enough data, but it‚Äôs good to double-check. Since you‚Äôve already run the stats cron job manually, make sure that it‚Äôs scheduled to run at an appropriate frequency in your site‚Äôs cron settings. Look into the Moodle logs for any errors or warnings related to statistics processing. That might give you more context on what‚Äôs going wrong. The mention of missing files usually refers to certain plugins or modules that may not be fully installed or could be corrupt. Check if all standard Moodle modules are present in your /mod folder.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Session Timeout Logout Report
ResponsesInList.Text: I understand how crucial accurate reporting is for your organization, especially regarding user activity in Moodle. Unfortunately, as you've noticed, Moodle typically only logs a user as "logged out" when they actively click the "Log Out" button. This can be a challenge since many users may not log out manually. One workaround is to adjust the session timeout settings. While Moodle doesn‚Äôt automatically log users out due to inactivity in a way that generates a report entry, you can set a shorter session timeout. This way, users will be logged out more frequently, and you might capture more accurate data in your reports.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Session Timeout Logout Report
ResponsesInList.Text: How about a .txt file 'report'? If you want totals, here's one way: A command line script to get activity for 24 hour period. (I use passwordless for DB CLI query so you don't see the -p option below): get24hr - contents mysql -u root -e "use moodle;select userid,action,other,ip,realuserid,origin,ip,timecreated from mdl_logstore_standard_log WHERE timecreated > UNIX_TIMESTAMP(NOW() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR);" > 24hours.txt; cat 24hours.txt|more; wc -l 24hours.txt That outputs to a 24hours.txt file and the wc gives total number of hits. Then, one can: fgrep 'loggedon' 24hours.txt |wc -l to get a total count on hits of those that logged on. And to get a total count of hits of those that logged out. If you wanted to keep a daily, one could add a date/time stamp to the name of the 24hours.txt file by adding -$(date +%Y%m%d%-H%M) making the name of the 24hours.txt file 24hours-$(date +%Y%m%d%-H%M).txt You could set up a cron job to do the above every 24 hours. Not logging out is a bad habit. ¬†Have concluded that might be encouraged by the¬† way resources/files are linked to in courses. ¬† If those links replace the moodle screen users forget they are logged on and simply close that window when they are done ... thus moodles session clean up eventually would force user to login again due to inactivity. 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List of courses not accessed in the previous year
ResponsesInList.Text:
That won't work because the user is irrelevant in this scenario and can't be grouped, and also the query would only return courses that have been accessed at least once, but not any that have never been accessed. You need to spin the query around, and perhaps limit to currently running courses and then left join on the mdl_user_last_access table to pick up where a course has never been accessed. I think this is what you're after: 
```text
SELECT c.id, c.shortname, MAX(la.timeaccess), DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(MAX(la.timeaccess)), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Last access time"
FROM mdl_course c
LEFT JOIN mdl_user_lastaccess la ON la.courseid = c.id
WHERE c.startdate <= UNIX_TIMESTAMP() AND c.enddate >= UNIX_TIMESTAMP()
GROUP BY c.id
ORDER BY MAX(la.timeaccess) desc;
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL queries to help with at-risk students
ResponsesInList.Text: Your questions don't quite match your subject, but I will give you some thoughts. 1) By default, all courses have a grade book. 2) The grade book could be updated automatically by quizzes, so your question doesn't make sense. Might you explain why knowing this is relevant? 3) You might be able to get to this with a custom SQL query. But why is this relevant? 4) Consider that the Moodle admin creates a course. The instructor clicks on the course to see that it is "alive." Is this what you mean by "setting up?" If so, you are then more interested in "first access." After the first access, a professor might create a quiz on one day, and another quiz on another day. So there is no "point" in time. You might need to define what you mean by "setting up."

```text
select distinct u.username, u.email, u.firstname, u.lastname, c.shortname, e.enrol


from mdl_user u


join mdl_role_assignments ra on ra.userid = u.id


join mdl_context x on x.id = ra.contextid


join mdl_course c on c.id = x.instanceid


join mdl_enrol e on e.courseid = c.id


where u.id in (


¬† ¬† select distinct r.userid


¬† ¬† from mdl_role_assignments r

¬† ¬† inner join mdl_course c on x.instanceid = c.id

```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participant Last Access Not Matching Logs
ResponsesInList.Text: After some more digging, the mismatched dates reflect work done offline in the Moodle app, rather than a traditional browser. It likely happened when the student accessed course activities offline in the Moodle mobile app, then their data/offline work was synchronized with Moodle when the student had network access again. The log entries indicate 'origin' records of both 'web' (accessing Moodle through a browser) and 'ws' (webservice - accessing via the Moodle app, which allows for offline activities). Thanks, Mary Beth

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity completion report questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vaya, for #1 - you can enable the additional filter in your reports through your course settings -- set the Group Mode to visible (or separate) groups. It will only enable you to filter by "groups" (not "groupings" -- but to show "groupings" in the filter, consider making a grouping per group so you can use them for filtering purposes) #2 - agreed, and makes for a good Moodle Tracker improvement suggestion : ) some sort of bulk activity completion editing. The only approach I found to help my fingers from all the clicking is to utilize the keyboard -- you can tab over to a box, and click enter -tab -tab- -tab enter to add and accept overwrite, then move to the next... that's all I got to offer from the front end to help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report Builder 4.3.3 Count function
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Shirley, There are a couple of improvements you can make to fix your report: You have a condition for "Completed = Yes" (which explains your " [...] courses that currently have a completion count of zero (0) are not reported. ") You are aggregating the column by Count (count of any value) when you should be aggregating by Sum (for a boolean column, this will be the sum of all true values) Hope that helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: We're interested in getting an idea of how many shells we created each term actually end up getting used by faculty.¬† Using database queries and the "Moodle Usage Statistics" plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_modstats ) I'm able to see, for example, the number of courses by category that have assignment activities .¬† The idea being courses without Assignments aren't being used.¬† This is helpful but not an entirely accurate assumption, however, since some faculty might simply use Moodle as a way to share files or links or as a launch point for an external tool. Another idea I had was identifying what a 'default' shell size is to ID courses not being used (aka, not having content uploaded) using the course size plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_coursesize ).¬† This plugin can inflate course sizes and this fails to account for courses that don't have file uploads increasing the disk footprint and instead rely on other activities. Another idea was to find a course last modified date.¬† Moodle's course table has this, but my understanding is this only records when changes via the course Settings menu have been saved.¬† This wouldn't track changes to the course like adding a file or modifying an assignment, for example.¬† There doesn't seem to be a universal last modified value for a course in the database. Has anyone found solutions to gathering usage data either through plugins or database queries that I might be missing?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: I haven't detected from what you posted what you mean when you say, "end up getting used by faculty." ¬†For example, do you mean that a faculty enters the course x times per day? ¬†Or do you mean the faculty forces students to use the system? ¬†Or do you mean that the faculty is modifying due dates? ¬†Or is " upload " content" what you are looking for versus modifying content? As an idea, might it be that you are interested in how often the particular faculty "enters the course?" ¬†Or how many resources and assignments are turned on for students? When one speaks about faculty or student "activity," I always wonder what they mean. ¬†Also, I wonder about why "number of times" is important. ¬†An "efficient" faculty or student might only need to access a course (like once) each week.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm looking for ways I can approximate what percentage of courses created for a given term are never utilized. My organization wants faculty to use Moodle. Not all faculty use it. So I'm attempting to identify a method to gather this information. I don't care who the faculty not using it are, I just want to see the data related to courses or activities. As I mentioned in my initial post, I have a percentage of courses that never get an assignment activity added. Obviously, not all faculty are going to use Moodle in the same way. Some might rely of other activity types. Some might simply post files or links. Others might only use an external LTI tool. I'm simply asking if others have experience attempting to identify this or similar information from Moodle's DB or if there are reporting tools that address these issues.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Consider creating a custom SQL query. Perhaps one is already created in Ad-hoc contributed report . In "English," the query would be something like, "Show me how many times all courses were accessed." ¬†For further refinement, you might say "by the person with instructor role." I took a quick look at the contributed reports, and I do see one query that might work for you, "Most active courses." ¬†I also see a report for "Least active or probably empty courses."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephen, You can also obtain course usage information from the course overview report which is available in standard Moodle if you enable Statistics on your site. For details, see the documentation Course overview report .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried your suggestion, Helen, and it works! This report provides a few different ways to look at course activity. So much will depend upon what Stephen considers "activity," but the course overview report is one quick way to get some statistics.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Usage Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the suggestion. I think custom database queries are going to be the better option in my case.

ResponsesInList.Title: User's accumulative time spent in course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, Can someone explain in plain words (even better with an example...) what "A sum up of the time delta between logstore_standard_log user's records, considering the a 2-hour session limit" mean? I am referring to the definition of the ad hoc report User's accumulative time spent in course . Had a interesting discussion with a guy who is obsessed with this and thinks that there is a high correlation between time and grading. By running this report and putting it on a scatter plot with linear regressions, I see that this is not case in basically all my courses (which makes total sense!). However, I would like to know exactly how this report track the time spent. Thanks! Javier

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User's accumulative time spent in course
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Javier, It is a fascinating piece of code. I know that some analytics platforms integrated with Moodle count the time spent by the number of clicks in a period. But this code seemed to calculate the user time spent based on the calculation of the deferences between each action/log time (timecreate) and the previous action time (@prevtime) in two hours. I can see the ambiguity in the code, and I am not sure if this code works fine and do the expected job, but I think we can use it to calculate the time that students spend on a quiz need 2 hours if we add some conditions like 'last two hours do this calculation or specify the module id'. But I am still unsure how this code calculates the time spent in two hours sessions without overriding or recalculating the same log points. I was trying to visualise the code, and I would like to share the screenshot below with you. Suppose we calculate the last two hours from a specific time, and the students left at 30 minutes after creating some logs. In that case, we can get the 'sumtime' as 30 minutes, but if the student did some work and then left and came back at the last minute to create a new log, then the sum time will be 2 hours even though that the user did not spend all the two hours doing work on the page. Hopefully, that adds to the conversation. Regards Mo

ResponsesInList.Text: As an Admin user, check the settings for 'PATH'.¬†¬† Moodle does have a setting for python that is not enabled by default.¬†¬† The suggested path for python you see on that screen is a guess ... it's not a discovery.¬†¬† Most linux platforms do have python installed. ResponsesInList.Title: SQL query to show grade breakdown as percentages
ResponsesInList.Text: Evening all. I'm new to Moodle and MySQL and hoping I can get some help with a query I've written.¬† I'm looking to create a report to show all the assignments per unit, and for each one the percentage of students who received a pass, merit or distinction as well as the percentage of students who have needed to resubmit. I've written the below, and it is showing the assignment names, pass, merit and distinction percentages.¬† However, it's not showing the correct unit IDs and the resubmission percentage is always showing as 0 which isn't correct as some students have needed to resubmit. Can someone maybe give me some insight into where I'm going wrong? SELECT gi.courseid AS unit_ID, a.name AS assignment_name, COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) AS total_submissions, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 3.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS pass_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 4.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS merit_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 5.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS distinction_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN g.attemptnumber = 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS resubmission_percentage FROM {assign} AS a LEFT JOIN {assign_submission} AS s ON a.id = s.assignment LEFT JOIN {assign_grades} AS g ON s.id = g.assignment JOIN {grade_grades} AS gg ON s.userid = gg.userid INNER JOIN {grade_items} AS gi ON gg.itemid = gi.id GROUP BY gi.courseid, a.name

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL query to show grade breakdown as percentages
ResponsesInList.Text: join grade_items to assign using the itemtype, itemmodule and iteminstance settings

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report to determine total users who have completed one course
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe the application Configurable Reports is different than the ad-hoc contributed reports. I played with the 4.0 version of Configurable Reports on the Mount Orange Demo site - and there was no functionality for Count. I use the ad-hoc contributed reports plugin, but I cannot get an accurate Course Completion Count - because I use cohorts as my preferred enrollment method. The Cohort object sadly does not have an end-date - so a third of my reports are overstated by students that were enrolled at one time and then moved to another set of courses. This SQL below - returns all expected rows of data - 1/3 of the results are overstated. 2/3 is verified as correct. SELECT Distinct c.id, ccat.name AS Course_category, c.fullname AS Course, CASE WHEN (cp.timeenrolled) is NULL then (cp.timecompleted) = 0 ELSE (cp.timecompleted) = 1 END AS 'Completions', COUNT(cp.timecompleted) AS 'Completions' FROM prefix_role_assignments AS ra JOIN prefix_context AS context ON context.id = ra.contextid AND context.contextlevel = 50 JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = context.instanceid JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_course_completions AS cp ON cp.course = c.id AND cp.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_course_categories AS ccat ON ccat.id = c.category WHERE (c.visible = 1) AND u.deleted = 0 AND u.suspended = 0 AND EXISTS ( SELECT ue.userid FROM prefix_user_enrolments ue JOIN prefix_enrol e ON e.id = ue.enrolid AND e.courseid WHERE ue.userid = u.id ) GROUP BY c.id ORDER BY c.fullname Kind Regards

I could see that the Orange Demo site allows plugins. In both Configurable Reports and Ad-hoc Queries plugins, you can write your own SQL. This is what I have always done. However, maybe these plugins can write the SQL for the user. I don't know. In your query, you are using the COUNT function. Does this query abort with a "COUNT not supported" error message? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report to determine total users who have completed one course
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't have SQL for your specific need, but I have this code I wrote to get the current number of students enrolled in all courses. You might want to explore my code to see if it helps you begin your own. /* Counts all users in a course, no filtering This is a modified version of my active student count query. */ SELECT c.fullname AS Course_Name, c.idnumber AS CourseNum, count(ue.userid) AS COUNT FROM prefix_course c JOIN prefix_enrol en ON en.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = ue.userid JOIN prefix_role_assignments asg ON u.id = asg.userid JOIN prefix_context con ON asg.contextid = con.id WHERE ue.status = 0 AND en.courseid = con.instanceid GROUP BY en.courseid ORDER BY c.idnumber DESC, count(*) DESC

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report to determine total users who have completed one course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Shirley, I hope this code will help you: Based on @Rick¬¥s code but modified to only count when course completions table have data, so the course is done. SELECT c.id, c.fullname AS Course_Name, count(ue.userid) AS COUNT FROM prefix_course c JOIN prefix_enrol en ON en.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = ue.userid JOIN prefix_role_assignments asg ON u.id = asg.userid JOIN prefix_context con ON asg.contextid = con.id JOIN prefix_course_completions AS cc ON cc.course = c.id AND cc.userid = u.id WHERE ue.status = 0 AND cc.timecompleted IS NOT NULL AND en.courseid = con.instanceid GROUP BY en.courseid ORDER BY c.idnumber DESC, count(*) DESC Good luck. (Remember to adapt the prefix to your DB)

ResponsesInList.Title: Query to find last date of login to a class
ResponsesInList.Text: I need a query that shows the last date that a student logged into a class. I found one on here and found a query that was almost right and tweaked it. Here is what I have: SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.id, u.email, c.fullname, #la.timeaccess, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess), '%d-%M-%Y %H:%i') AS "Last access time" FROM prefix_user_lastaccess la JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = la.userid JOIN prefix_course c ON c.id = la.courseid WHERE c.fullname LIKE '%2023FA%' AND u.username REGEXP¬† '[0-9]' ORDER BY c.shortname I have it limited by semester and students v all users, and it's almost what I need. If a student has not logged in to a class at all, it doesn't show. I have tried some ISNULL commands, and it either won't run or returns that no student has ever logged into any class. I need it to return the date if the student has logged in or 'never', 'none', or similar if they have not. Does anyone have any suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Query to find last date of login to a class
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps you have already visited https://docs.moodle.org/402/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports to get some ideas. ¬†If not, it's a good place to start. You should think about "what do I define as a student being in a course." ¬†Do you want to consider unenrolled students? ¬†Suspended students? ¬†So another place to start is by seeing if you can create a query of all students in a course, and then see if your query results match your enrollment criteria. I cannot say that my example, below, is perfect or matches your criteria, but it is the query that I use that gives me a list of all students in all courses in my (rather small) Moodle. ¬†It does not provide the last access, however. ¬†If I wanted to do this, I would have to join it, somehow, to the logstore table. Perhaps it will help you. /* LIST ALL ACTIVE STUDENTS IN ALL COURSES --------------------------------------- This query works, and finds all active, enrolled, non-admin, students in a course. 11/19/2020 Filters explained: e.status 0 non-hidden enrolment methods ue.status 0 = not suspended at the course level. ra.roleid 5 = student u.idnumber < 99995 are for non-admin users, as Rick has decided to use these. c.idnumber > 300. Rick uses the idnumber for real courses. ¬†3 means moodle 3, and then xx for the course sequence. Notes: 3 is a placeholder for moodle version. */ SELECT c.shortname AS CourseName, c.idnumber AS CourseIDNum, c.id AS CourseID, ue.userid AS StudentID, u.lastname AS LastName, u.firstname AS FirstName, u.email AS Email, 3 AS moodleversion FROM prefix_course c JOIN prefix_enrol e ON e.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON ue.enrolid = e.id JOIN prefix_context con ON con.instanceid = c.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON (ra.contextid = con.id AND ra.userid = ue.userid) JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = ue.userid WHERE e.status = 0 AND ue.status = 0 AND ra.roleid = 5 AND c.idnumber > 300 AND u.idnumber < 99995 ORDER BY c.idnumber DESC, ue.userid

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad-hoc database queries plugin complains at reusing one parameter twice in the query
ResponsesInList.Text:
I was trying to create a custom report where I parse the file from the URL like this: 
```text
    SELECT CONCAT('https',CHAR(58),'//example.com/report.php',CHAR(63),'contentID=',l.contentID)
    FROM {reporter_links} l
    JOIN {files} f
    ON l.fileid = f.id
    WHERE f.contextid = (SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 5)), '/', -1))
    AND f.itemid=(SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 8)), '/', -1))
    AND f.filename != '.'
```
 This is the error I get: 
```text
Error when executing the query: ERROR: Incorrect number of query parameters. Expected 2, got 1.
```
 I figured out that reusing :url is the culprit. The horrible workaround was to introduce :url2 and paste the link twice in the report GUI. Is there any other way to solve this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad-hoc database queries plugin complains at reusing one parameter twice in the query

ResponsesInList.Title: Tracking question completion time in quizzes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Is there a table on the moodle DB that can track question completion time for each question in a given quiz? I have tried looking into mdl_quiz_attempts and mdl_question_attempts and while the first one shows me completion time for each quiz I cannot seem to find the same in question_attempts. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tracking question completion time in quizzes
ResponsesInList.Text: I might be wrong, but the Moodle database does not keep track of every keystroke within a quiz question. If every quiz question is on its own separate page, meaning that the "Next" button is used, they database might keep track of this. I would start exploring this by looking at the logstore table. So, a student is presented a multiple choice question. They click on choice A, then change their mind, and click on choice B. After answering other questions, they return to this one and click choice C. Or, they return to this question, look at it, and do nothing. I think you would want all time on this question, right? And if more than one question is on a page, how would you determine which question the student is reconsidering? Perhaps the desire to get 'time per question" could only be possible if only one question is shown per page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 4.0, trying to get a custom relational report that crosses users and course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Zenit, YOu can use the following approach to connect users with their courses. FROM prefix_course_categories AS cat JOIN prefix_course AS mc ON mc.category = cat.id JOIN prefix_context AS context ON context.instanceid = mc.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = context.id JOIN prefix_user mu ON ra.userid = mu.id But I am unsure if this way of approaching the time students spend in the course or activity will give you accurate results. Best wishes Mo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-Hoc Report: New Enrolments in the Last 24 hours
ResponsesInList.Text:
I've made some progress but got stuck again. When I reduce the time frame from 48 hours (in the code below) to 24 hours the number of records returned comes to just 2. There have been way more enrolments in the last 24 hours than that. 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT user2.firstname AS Firstname,
    user2.lastname AS Lastname,
    user2.email AS Email,
    course.shortname AS CourseName,
    role.shortname as Role,
    FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timestart) AS enrolment_date
FROM prefix_course as course
JOIN prefix_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = course.id
JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id
JOIN prefix_user AS user2 ON ue.userid = user2.id
JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = user2.id
JOIN prefix_role role ON ra.roleid = role.id
WHERE course.idnumber LIKE 'UILX%' AND ue.timestart >= (UNIX_TIMESTAMP() - 172800) 
ORDER BY course.shortname
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course statistics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mo, you rock ... finally I came up with this one: SELECT u.firstname as Forename ,u.lastname as Surname, mcm.completion as Completiontype, cmc.completionstate as Completionstate, ####ACTIVITY NAME (CASE WHEN mcm.module = 6 THEN (SELECT ma.name FROM {choice} AS ma WHERE ma.id = mcm.instance) WHEN mcm.module = 10 THEN (SELECT mf.name FROM {forum} AS mf WHERE mf.id = mcm.instance) WHEN mcm.module = 15 THEN (SELECT mq.name FROM {lesson} AS mq WHERE mq.id = mcm.instance) WHEN mcm.module = 28 THEN (SELECT mw.name FROM {wordcloud} AS mw WHERE mw.id = mcm.instance) END) AS activityname FROM {course} as mc JOIN {course_modules} as mcm ON mcm.course = mc.id JOIN {modules} as mm ON mcm.module = mm.id JOIN {course_modules_completion} as cmc ON cmc.coursemoduleid = mcm.id JOIN {user} as u on u.id = cmc.userid WHERE mc.id = 9 ORDER BY u.lastname,u.id In other words I needed a round bracket... but now it works ... have thanks!!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Comparison of Adaptive vs deferred feedback analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodle community, I have been trialing the adaptive mode in quizzes in my large 1st year course. I would like to have some sort of comparison of how this has benefitted students, but what I thought I could do is not working. My thinking was to look at the quiz statistics and calculate on first attempt or first try, vs last attempt/last try, but this makes no difference. I then tried changing the quiz to 'deferred' feedback and regrading, but htis made no change. Is there a way to do this? kind regards Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Comparison of Adaptive vs deferred feedback analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Gareth, Answers on a first try in adaptive mode and answers in deferred¬†feedback mode shouldn't differ much, in principle, since it's a first try and a single try, which is about the same. Obviously, answers on the last try in adaptive mode should normally be better than on the first try or in deferred¬†feedback mode. In general, the adaptive mode would be more appropriate for formative assessments, while the deferred feedback mode would be more appropriate for summative assessments. Personally, I use the adaptive mode even for summative assessments because I consider that it is of little use for students to be blocked without having any clues, and without having one or more attempts to answer questions. Indeed, in my view, the primary purpose of quizzes, both formative and summative, is for students to learn about a topic. The summative aspect is well taken into account in adaptive mode thanks to the penalties for each try. Better students get more points for answering questions correctly on the first try, while weaker students lose points for answering correctly only on the second or more tries, or for not getting the correct answer even after the number of tries allowed. So, unless I want to do a very strict summative evaluation, which I don't necessarily see the benefit for the students, I don't use the deferred feedback mode. There are obviously a multitude of cases other than mine where the deferred¬†feedback mode is useful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Get the analytics predictions for a specific user within the Moodle database
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! I need to be able to map the predictions of the Analytics models with the specific users (userid). Do you know if there's a way of doing that by quering the Moodle database ? I've been trying to join the 'prefix_analytics_predictions' table with others tables to get the user id target of the prediction but I didn't succeed I hope you can help me! Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Get the analytics predictions for a specific user within the Moodle database
ResponsesInList.Text: Try something like: SELECT * FROM {analytics_predictions} ap JOIN { context } cx on cx.id = ap.contextid JOIN {course} c on (c.id = cx.instanceid AND cx.contextlevel = 50) JOIN {user_enrolments} ue on ue.id = ap.sampleid JOIN {user} u on u.id = ue.userid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Get the analytics predictions for a specific user within the Moodle database
ResponsesInList.Text: That works perfectly! I was missing the fact that the sampleid matches the user_enrolments id

DB tweaks - for which DB service?¬† MySQL or MariaDB ... while MariaDB is supposed to be a drop in replacement for MySQL, there's enough of a difference between them to know which.¬†¬† Check the config.php file of your site. My suggestion about installing MySQL Tuner ... that's a perl script, not installable via Moodle Admin. https://github.com/major/MySQLTuner-perl You migrated to a new server for a reason ... one reason for migration is having more resources (memory/space) of server for the DB for your Moodle. 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site logging not working after migration
ResponsesInList.Text: What version of MariaDB? Exception ignored in shutdown function tool_log\log\manager::dispose: Error writing to database In the config.php file is a DB user and pass for that user. Is that user superuser?¬†¬† If not does that DB user have the ability to create tables as well as 'dispose' of them? Query ... below is super user ... you replace your DB user seen in config.php. mysql> show grants for 'root'@'localhost'; POST Content-Length of 100585931 bytes exceeds the limit of 57671680 bytes in Unknown on line 0 You have a max limit of 57671680 bytes.¬† Whatever was attempting to write to DB tried to use 100585931 bytes. PHP: php -i |grep max post_max_size? max_input_vars? IS upload max size = to post_max_size DB: mysql> show variables like 'max_%'; I don't use Nginx but apache has also a max size for uploads ... normally set to -1 with mod thus 'unlimited' - I've never had to set that. https://moodledev.io/general/development/policies/php says: PHP 8.0 can be used with Moodle 3.11.8, Moodle 4.0.2 and later releases. See MDL-70745 for details. PHP 7.4 can be used with Moodle 3.8.3, Moodle 3.9 and later releases. It is also the minimum supported version for Moodle 4.1. See MDL-66260 for details. Where did you find the error log ... in a directory of Moodle code? If so, what was that directory? 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site logging not working after migration
ResponsesInList.Text: Use site admin search box for 'logs'. Several items but in Manage log stores /admin/settings.php?section=managelogging which is enabled? the one that is enabled has settings. The Standard Log does have a setting for how long to keep logs for: Default is never delete logs.¬†¬† That translates to a very large table. Maybe too large to display. comment in moodle admin of that area reads: This specifies the length of time you want to keep logs about user activity. Logs that are older than this age are automatically deleted. It is best to keep logs as long as possible, in case you need them, but if you have a very busy server and are experiencing performance problems, then you may want to lower the log lifetime. Values lower than 30 are not recommended because statistics may not work properly. And the 'fun' continues! 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Text: One of the errors you reported earlier: POST Content-Length of 100585931 bytes exceeds the limit of 57671680 bytes in Unknown on line 0 quick explanation I gave: You have a max limit of 57671680 bytes.¬† Whatever was attempting to write to DB tried to use 100585931 bytes. So there are no error_log files in any of the code directories of your Moodle? Think, I've asked before ... Does your cPanel have a Terminal icon? Does your cPanel have a Git icon? I have a server that has been running somewhere near 13 years+ now. query to find largest tables: select table_schema as database_name, table_name, round( (data_length + index_length) / 1024 / 1024, 2) as total_size, round( (data_length) / 1024 / 1024, 2) as data_size, round( (index_length) / 1024 / 1024, 2) as index_size from information_schema.tables where table_schema not in ('information_schema', 'mysql', 'performance_schema' ,'sys') and table_type = 'BASE TABLE' -- and table_schema = 'your database name' order by total_size desc limit 10 Query to find lardatabase_name ¬†¬†¬† table_name ¬†¬†¬† total_size ¬†¬†¬† data_size ¬†¬†¬† index_size moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_grade_grades_history ¬†¬†¬† 683.24 ¬†¬†¬† 249.00 ¬†¬†¬† 434.24 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_files ¬†¬†¬† 302.77 ¬†¬†¬† 118.90 ¬†¬†¬† 183.87 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_question ¬†¬†¬† 277.84 ¬†¬†¬† 267.30 ¬†¬†¬† 10.54 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_question_attempts ¬†¬†¬† 172.02 ¬†¬†¬† 141.41 ¬†¬†¬† 30.60 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_question_attempt_steps ¬†¬†¬† 129.30 ¬†¬†¬† 60.38 ¬†¬†¬† 68.93 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_qtype_match_subquestions ¬†¬†¬† 120.37 ¬†¬†¬† 120.22 ¬†¬†¬† 0.15 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_grade_grades ¬†¬†¬† 99.88 ¬†¬†¬† 45.21 ¬†¬†¬† 54.66 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_assignfeedback_editpdf_annot ¬†¬†¬† 76.38 ¬†¬†¬† 57.83 ¬†¬†¬† 18.55 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_question_attempt_step_data ¬†¬†¬† 69.64 ¬†¬†¬† 49.84 ¬†¬†¬† 19.80 moodle ¬†¬†¬† mdl_message ¬†¬†¬† 69.14 ¬†¬†¬† 63.59 ¬†¬†¬† 5.55 There is no reason to keep all in log_store_standard_log IMHO .¬†¬† So the events on that server are set for 1 academic year. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site logging not working after migration
ResponsesInList.Text: Very significant info there ... Initial posting of the problem you stated: "Recently migrated a moodle site to a new server and restored," So you migrated from something ... what was that a locally hosted server? One that was dedicated to just your entity/hostname .... the only one on that server? Significance of server info and can see that hosting might be your problem. Shared Hosting with that single IP address. Means there are other customers on same server and you have limits/caps? ;; ANSWER SECTION: 220.212.76.41.in-addr.arpa. 14401 IN¬†¬†¬† PTR¬†¬†¬† boilerroom.dedicated.co.za megs.co.za ? While a dig on the IP shows dedicated.co.za DNS wise ... is it really dedicated? IF so, why wouldn't you have greater access to server? One of those limits is how often one can run cron job.¬†¬† Recommendation is for server to run cron job once per minute.¬† All shared hosting systems I have been in don't allow that. running apache as apache_php_fpm up ‚Äúapache_php_fpm‚Äù That means there is more config to apache ... the php_fmp part. sshd up ‚Äússhd‚Äù is ok. You supposedly have ssh access to server but have never set it up/used it. (Terminal icon would be better/easier!¬† Maybe you just need to request of provider to install Terminal module in cPanel. Swap 7.51% ‚ÄúSwap‚Äù is ok Server has SWAP space and is using it.¬† Am almost willing to bet that SWAP is mostly DB related.¬† Running top from the command line would tell. Kernel Version 3.10.0-1160.59.1.el7.x86_64 Shows your Linux is CentOS Enterprise release 7.¬† A long term support version whose end of life is coming up June 30, 2024 (that sounds a long way off, but out of sight ... out of mind ... and you. you/provider needs to move from that before crunch time. You said you used 'super user' creds for DB?¬†¬† If there are other customers on that server (which is also a shared DB server) bet you didn't. In phpmyadmin do you see the following DB's: information_schema mysql performance_schema sys Probably don't ... phpmyadmin is not normally configured to run under super user creds. But, if you had ssh access/ or terminal and could su to root, and logged onto the DB server via client with super user creds you could see those databases. That would also mean you could install MySQL Tuner. Disk Usage shows 168.99 GB / used but how large is the disk slice you can use on shared hosting?¬†¬† Doesn't show free space. Do see this: Disk / (/) 25% ... IF 169 G is 25% of the total space on disk to which you have access then that's good - you have a lot of space.¬†¬† And could run a dev clone of your moodle site. At time of you viewing: Memory Used 48.50% About 50% of the memory ... if your moodle runs cron?¬† if all of your users login to moodle to do a timed test? Ask your provider to install MySQL Tuner and run it with super user creds to see what tweaks to DB might be needed. A moodle runs best if most of the DB can be in memory of server (balancing act on a server that runs all - apache, php-fmp, db server, other services), cron job runs the recommended once per minute, and the admin of the server (both Moodle admin and the OS admin) maintain - keeps things up to date! 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site logging not working after migration
ResponsesInList.Text: "tried to fix" ... and what did you try? " restored locally on my pc with xampp " ... not same *shared* environment¬† ... so my conclusion, not same and proves nothing.¬† xampp not CentOS either thus not really a comparison!¬†¬† Now replicate all of those moodles on your xampp environment then it would be closer to server ... would it not? " other moodle's running on different domains on the same server " First time you mentioned that, but ... your cPanel info shared showed only 2 domains, did it not? Now we are looking at the total resources needed to run multiple moodles on/in same *shared* environment.¬†¬† All of those sites cron jobs running the recommended once per minute.¬†¬† And the DB server (localhost) that host the DB's for all moodles is handling all of them.¬†¬† That would equate to more resources of the single server for each of those DB's.¬†¬† Thus MySQL Tuner would be of more importance IMHO. Plus, if each of those configured the same, the php-fpm piece ... has separate configuration ... have you compared all those? 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Problem with reports (training sessions)
ResponsesInList.Text:
I use moodle 3.9.11 with training sessions¬†3.7.0 (build 2019112200). Students have permission to see their reports. Some users insist that there is a problem with reports. Not many, but enough to trouble me. They say for example that¬†although they had viewed a scrom activity for... 2 hours, the report shows only 1. In addition, a couple of them claimed that when they viewed their report after 2-3 days, time in some activities was not the same. It was less. Œët first Œô thought they were wrong, but now I am thinking something is going wrong. One student had almost 40hours in "Other course use time" and only a few hours in activities. I found it strange since student says that he was viewing scrom activities all this time. I have done many tests but I haven't found any error.¬†
what can go wrong? is there a possibility that the hours are not being measured correctly? And apart from that, how can the hours be reduced for some students (2 so far)? All these students attend different courses. I cannot find any pattern between them. Everything else works fine on the site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad hoc Reports - Courseid vs Course Name
ResponsesInList.Text: I picked SQL Code below from the Adhoc Reports and¬† I have used to get specific information about a particular student but it wont give me the correct course name. Instead, it gives the grades associated with the displayed courseID who name I need to capture. I am not an expert in SQL. Note that I have used the Firstname field for Student Registration Numbers. Kindly help. Thank you. Code is Here SELECT user2.firstname AS Firstname, user2.lastname AS Lastname, course.fullname AS Course, prefix_grade_items.courseid, prefix_grade_items.itemmodule , prefix_grade_items.itemname , ROUND(prefix_grade_items.grademax,0) as grademax , ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) AS finalgrade , from_unixtime(prefix_grade_grades.timecreated) AS timecreated FROM prefix_course AS course left outer JOIN prefix_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = course.id left outer JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id left outer JOIN prefix_user AS user2 ON ue.userid = user2.id left outer join prefix_grade_grades¬† on user2.id = prefix_grade_grades.userid left outer join¬† ¬†prefix_grade_items¬† ¬†on prefix_grade_grades.itemid = prefix_grade_items.id where user2.firstname ='BCC01/0150/2018' AND itemmodule='quiz' AND itemname ='ORDINARY EXAM' ORDER BY Course

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc Reports - Courseid vs Course Name
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, those are odd looking firstnames you've got going on there 'BCC01/0150/2018'. The courseid is the id field in the course table. You don't need to display it, but it's useful to distinguish it from another course that might have the same name. Which seems to be the case with your example. The query, as you have it there, will only pull grade items for quizzes that have the title "ORDINARY EXAM", so will not return any grades from any other activity or quizzes with different names. If you want to show the grades for a particular course, then use the course id in the where. e.g. 
```text

```
 where user2.firstname ='BCC01/0150/2018' AND itemmodule='quiz' AND itemname ='ORDINARY EXAM' AND course.id=3022

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automated Analytics Report
ResponsesInList.Text: A user with tool/inspire:listinsights capability will automatically receive notifications from an insight. You can configure notifications in your User menu > Preferences > Notification preferences.

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL help - students who enrolled in a course after a specific date
ResponsesInList.Text:
I'm using an Ad Hoc query to count how many students accessed courses since a certain date. I also want to limit the user count to students who enrolled in the course after a date. I'm having trouble with the last part - where does Moodle store a user's enrollment date for a course? Here's the query so far: 
```text
SELECT c.id, count(u.id)


FROM prefix_user u


JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON (ue.userid = u.id)


JOIN prefix_enrol en ON (en.id = ue.enrolid)


JOIN prefix_course c ON (c.id = en.courseid)


JOIN prefix_context cx ON (cx.instanceid = c.id AND cx.contextlevel = 50)


LEFT JOIN prefix_user_lastaccess ul ON (ul.courseid = en.courseid AND ul.userid = u.id)


WHERE ul.timeaccess > unix_timestamp('2022-09-01')


AND (SELECT count(1)¬†


FROM prefix_role_assignments ra¬†


WHERE ra.userid = u.id AND ra.roleid = (5) AND ra.contextid = cx.id)
¬†> 0


GROUP by c.id


ORDER by count(u.id) DESC
```
 Thank you so much for any help or insight. I'm very new to this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL help - students who enrolled in a course after a specific date
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I think you've already the information it's in the table user_enrolments -> timecreated or timestart Dominique.

ResponsesInList.Title: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: I have users who have been assigned as Managers of Categories. I want to generate and email reports to them using the ad-hoc database queries plugin. I wrote an SQL statement which approriately filters the results to only the Category in question. So now I'm trying to set the "automically email results...' value and it only lists my system-wide admins. I double checked and under Site Adminstration > Users > Permissions > Define Roles > Manager¬† ¬†I have "report/customsql:view" set to Allow. What am I missing? Can we only send the email results of the ad-hoc querries to system-level admins?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Tay You can add any valid Moodle username to the list to email reports to. The pull down list only shows the Administrators. I presume this is to keep the list short. It doesn't show the other usernames, but if you enter them manually, it works. If you choose a username that does not exist, it will complain when you try to save the report. Those users don't need any permissions set at all to get the email. The permissions are only needed for directly accessing the reports via url or the Site admin menu.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried to enter it manually (both by username and by email), and it simply won't add them. There is no "complaint" it just won't let them add them at all. The only ones it will take are the ones on the drop down list (who are all admins). Can you check this on a 3.11 site to confirm that your experience is different than mine?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you set to the 'Run' type from 'On demand' to one of the 'Scheduled' options?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, that is correct. Like I said, I can send it to myself and other admins just fine. But it won't let me send it to anyone else. I think even checked the permissions of the user I had in mind and that didn't fix it. Even when I enabled them to view system-wide reports, they still don't appear as an option in this window.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Here's how I am doing it now: Set up a System level role and set View custom queries report - report/customsql:view to Allow Assign the users you want to get mailed reports to that system role In the report set "Who can access this query" to "Anyone who can view this report (report/customsql:view)" and set the schedule. Then they show up on the list to mail to.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: By the way, there is nothing wrong about assigning this permission to the Manager role if that is what you need. But my experience is that when I do, clients always then want to email some reports to folks who are not Managers. So, in the end I always end up creating a separate system level role for this anyway.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Randy, that was super helpful and did the trick! I created a system-wide "Analyst" role and it looks like it's going to work great.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permissions to email ad-hoc database queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Nice! Glad that worked out.

ResponsesInList.Title: Site wide SQL report last access to course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys, I'm new to Moodle can someone help me with the SQL for a site-wide report on the following fields but i should be able to customise the date range. I'm using the configurable reports. Student last access to courses: First name Surname Student Number Email address Last access to course Course

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site wide SQL report last access to course
ResponsesInList.Text: You can view all kinds of examples of SQL in List of SQL Contributed reports . I started with Randy Thornton's contribution for Last access time of users to a course The basic SQL code looks something like the one below. ¬†You can add more filters and criteria. ¬†For example, the SQL below will show all people in a course instead of "only students." SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.id, u.email, c.fullname, #la.timeaccess, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Last access time" FROM mdl_user_lastaccess la JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = la.userid JOIN mdl_course c ON c.id = la.courseid order by c.id, u.lastname, u.firstname; You can add a "where c.id in (123, 456, 789)" line to limit the selection to specific courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site wide SQL report last access to course
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much is is exactly what I needed excellent! Can you kindly advise how i can add in a filter to search a range month or year?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site wide SQL report last access to course
ResponsesInList.Text: I would make my life easier by swapping "LAT" for "Last access time". Then the query could become: SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.id, u.email, c.fullname, #la.timeaccess, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "LAT" FROM mdl_user_lastaccess la JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = la.userid JOIN mdl_course c ON c.id = la.courseid where c.id = 93610 having LAT between "2022-01" and "2022-03" order by c.id, u.lastname, u.firstname; Of course, you can make the dates be whatever you wish in that "having" line of code. I also added the "where" line for a specific course. However, this new query will only return students who had a LAT between those two dates, which is different from "which students accessed the course between two dates, and what was their access time?" So you have to think about what question you are trying to answer. Perhaps you are seeing how SQL works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site wide SQL report last access to course

ResponsesInList.Title: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
ResponsesInList.Text: Problem: Limited Knowledge of Moodle Hamstrings Quality Course Design and Facilitation Quality course design with Moodle is limited by the familiarity of the designer / instructor who ¬†builds / teaches the course. They often do not know what they need to learn next and do not proactively seek out further professional development with Moodle (without incentives). Instead, they typically 'call someone' to find out how to do something in Moodle because they want 'just-in-time-learning'. Solution: Marry Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development Imagine if we were able to combine learning analytics data from Moodle with a smart, Customer Service chatbot? Example: Just take something simple, like the Moodle Assignement type. We can bring a faculty member on a learning path to iterate improvements to their use of this activity. All of their Moodle Assignments reflect their current knowledge level (Lean Prompt + Grade Points + File Submission). We could run analytics on the common settings for all of the Moodle Assignments in their course and detect that they don't have (1) activity completion checked (2) marking guide setup, (3) accepting online submissions, etc. We could expand the list. But here is the important point: We could create a chatbot to popup with suggestions for their 'Next Challenge' on how to 'Moodle Up' their Moodle Assignments, by, say, adding a Marking Guide to make it easier to grade. As you think about this from a pedagogical standpoint, there are iterative sequences we could bring end-users through: Main Course Page = Cluttered, High Use of Descriptions Showing on Main Page > Using Labels to Chunk and Organize > Learning How to Clean up Main Course Page, create Module Overviews, etc. Assignment Prompts = ¬†Long, exhaustive prose and Links > Creating Headers to Organize > HTML Tips to Reduce Cognitive Overload > Use of Accordions to Organize and Show/Hide Content Multimedia = Low detection of Multimedia in Course > How to add External URL Resource / Embed > How to Embed Videos > How to Organize a Multimedia 'Set' File Downloads = Detecting High Number of Documents on Main Course Page > How to use Moodle Files to chunk downloads with files that go together You all probably know quite a few more possibilities . . . !! Just imagine a little chatbot which pops up every once in awhile with a 'Want to Moodle Up?' box and a suggestion to help you 'Moodle Up' your skills in designing with Moodle. This would create *tremendous* leverage for those of us who provide Moodle support to our end-users. We have plenty of tutorials. We can direct them to take webinars. We can point them to Moodle Academy . But this type of 'scaled' professional development‚Äîdelivered in a 'just-in-time' way (based on analytics of their actual Moodle habits), would be a powerful way to improve Moodle skills at scale . I also think it would keep end-users in that 'flow state', because it is tailored to their current level‚Äîgiving them just enough new challenge without overwhelming them. I would love to see Moodle HQ think about something like this for future versions of Moodle. It could even be keyed to integrate with resources on Moodle Academy.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
ResponsesInList.Text: Great suggestion!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
ResponsesInList.Text: It's a nice idea, but between writing the spec, briefing the developers, QA and integration into Moodle Core etc I suspect the financial cost would be between $AU 50K to 100K. That is a wild stab in the dark estimate and I'd be interested to hear alternatives.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
ResponsesInList.Text: This very idea was proposed and worked on in quite a bit of detail at the first US Moodle Moot in 2015 by Michelle Moore, who now of course, works for Moodle US. That original idea was worked out in some detail, but what Moodle HQ did with it was make the User tours feature. They were not ready to do more with it than that at the time. Perhaps now they are.

ResponsesInList.Title: Easy Enrolments Plugin - SQL to pull Pass Code (using configurable reports plugin)
ResponsesInList.Text: Reposted from Enrolment Thread ( Moodle in English: Easy Enrolments Plugin - SQL to pull Pass Code (using configurable reports plugin) ) Sorry this would be better placed here. Hope that is ok. Dear All, I hope everyone is keeping well. I am desperately trying to find the Table/field that would allow me to pull in my SQL course report with the code needed to enter the course using Easy Enrolments. Report method -Configurable reports plugin SQL (tables I have tried Enrol table / enrol - Moodle LMS 3.9 Database schema / Zoola Analytics ) I am after the Enrolment Method - Easy Enrolment Code Current SQL report (sorry not very tidy as a little rusty but might help people if it is ok) ( constructed using the popular ad-hoc contributed reports - MoodleDocs ) Select cat.id as categoryid, cat.name as categoryname, c.id as courseid, c.fullname as FullCourseName, c.shortname as ShortCourseName, c.summary as CourseSummary, c.format as CourseFormat, c.startdate as CourseStartDate, c.enddate as CourseEndDate, c.timecreated as CourseCreatedDate, c.timemodified as CourseLastModified, concat('',c.fullname,'') as courselink, e.enrol AS enrolmethod, e.password as enrolcode From prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_course_categories as cat on cat.id = c.category JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON e.id = c.id I look forward to hearing your thoughts and a big thank you in advance. Many thanks, K

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  Easy Enrolments Plugin - SQL to pull Pass Code (using configurable reports plugin)
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to know what the value is for this particular plugin in the en.enrol field. Standard ones are those such as 'manual' and 'self'. Look at that table to fined out what that is. Then you need to then find in what column it stored the code. For example, the Self-enrolment method stores the enrolment key in the column called 'password'. This plugin may store it there or in perhaps one of the various custom values columns. You will have to take a look at that to find them. This report by S√©verin will help you with the logic, too. https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Lists_.22Totally_Opened_Courses.22_.28visible.2C_opened_to_guests.2C_with_no_password.29
