ResponsesInList.Title: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Where should I start to use Google Analytics on Moodle? Is the section below related with Google Analytics? And how can I use this part? Thank you. Best,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: You should start by finding out about the legal issues of using it. Use of Google Analytics is illegal in the EU because it violates user privacy under GDPR (sources: 1 , 2 , 3 ). If you have students from the EU, it is illegal to use it on them. If you have students in any country or location that has a national or local law on data privacy, you will need to find out whether you are violating the law by using it. There are a number of privacy respecting analytics that are legal in the EU and other places, including Matomo , Plausible , Fathom , Simple Analytics , and others.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ynt: Re: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Really? I don't know Google Analytics for now and I am supposed to learn for Moodle. But of course, if there is an issue as this, we should look for the other tools like you suggest. Is this part only about Google Analytics or what? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ynt: Re: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: That screen shows part of the internal Moodle analytics engine, which you can learn about here in the documentation: https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Analytics_quick_guide . This system is part of Moodle and works on the data inside of Moodle itself created by user activity: who uses what courses and what activities how often, and other things like that. It has a number of "models" already built in that you can use, but you can also build your own models if you want other types of analytics. It can send messages and notify you about things that are going on.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ynt: Re: Ynt: Re: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your explainations.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ynt: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Isn't there anybody who suggests using Google Analytics on Moodle? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ynt: Using Google Analytics on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Selma, There are several analytics services available to get an idea of the traffic on your site. Some are free others paid, some complex others simple to use. I think Google Analytics is free but it seems a bit complicated to use. It all depends on the information you are looking for. For example, if you have "Guest access" on your Moodle site and want to know the number and origin of visitors, and the pages visited, you can use for example Web-Stat (free or US$¬†9.50 per month) or LuckyOrange (free or US$¬†18 per month) which are easy to use. These services also have options to make data collection GDPR compliant. There are many other companies that offer this kind of service (do a Google search ) but the prices are often high.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad-hoc database queries: Problems with Link in Query
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, we're using Moodle 3.11.4 and the latest release of ad-hoc Report 4.1. We want to show a link in the report with the text Link. Right now we are using the folling SELECT statement: CONCAT("%%WWWROOT%%/mod/assign/view.php%%Q%%id=",cm.id, "&action=grading") AS "Link" This states shows: https://path.to.websiteroot/mod/assign/view.php?id=1360&action=grading as a link and we can open it. But what we want is: Link and this should be clickable to open the selected page. I#ve read in the documentation that the folling statement should work: CONCAT('Link') AS "Link" Unfortunately this is not showing as a link. Instead the report shows it as plain text:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-hoc database queries: Problems with Link in Query
ResponsesInList.Text: The Ad-hoc database queries has its own peculiar method of constructing URL links, as it mentions in its Notes where you build the query. You have to use its method: you don't put in any HTML code in the CONCAT statements to make the links. It builds the HTML for you. Otherwise, as you notice, it just spits out the link in full as plain text. Please see this section in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page on how this works including sample code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-hoc database queries: Problems with Link in Query

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-hoc database queries: Problems with Link in Query
ResponsesInList.Text: Most welcome. Glad that was helpful. It gave me the chance to finally document how it works. That method makes creating links much quicker than having to fiddle with the html and quotes, etc. But it is non-standard.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-hoc database queries: Problems with Link in Query
ResponsesInList.Text: This is excellent, I figured out my query. Thank you

SELECT u.id AS ' URL id', /*DISTINCT*/ CONCAT("%%WWWROOT%%/url/view.php%%Q%%id=1010171", cm.module) AS "link module" , u.course, cm.course, c.shortname, u.name AS 'url name',/*u.intro AS 'URL intro', u.externalurl,*/ cm.module FROM prefix_url AS u JOIN prefix_course AS c ON u.course = c.id JOIN prefix_course_modules AS cm ON cm.course = c.id WHERE u.externalurl LIKE '%ensemble.viterbo%'

ResponsesInList.Title: Outline Report for Student
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to be able to allow my students to see their 'Outline Report'. The one that I as Administrator/Teacher can see in the student profile: Dashboard - Courses - Course Name - Participants - John Doe - Reports - Outline report Does Anyone know how I might accomplish this? What would be the best way for them to access their 'Outline Report'? Thanks so much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Outline Report for Student
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! There is a capability to control who could see the Outline Report called 'report/outline:viewuserreport'. So an admin could go to Site administration > Users > Permissions > Define roles, edit Student role and change 'report/outline:viewuserreport' to 'Allow'. This way the student would be able to see their own Outline Report from their profile. You can find more information about how to manage roles on https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Managing_roles . I hope this helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Outline Report for Student
ResponsesInList.Text: And if you use the filter codes plugin, you can add a link such as this to the top of the courses so it sends students to their outline report (instead of having them go find the link in their course profile): a href="/report/outline/user.php?id={userid}&course={courseid}&mode=outline"

completion 3/2/2022 10:50 Completed 3/2/2022 10:52 Completed 3/2/2022 11:06 Completed (achieved pass grade) 3/4/2022 9:35 Course completion 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed (achieved pass grade) 9/03/22, 13:43 9/03/22, 13:43 I was not able to understand if this behavior is normal or did we setup something wrong in the system. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: How often is the Cron job running to course completion? Completion marks as started Calculate regular completion data Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your reply. The cron was set up to run every hour (server runs on Microsoft IIS ) now it has been lowered to 5 minutes, if this was the reason it would fix the next sessions but i need to find a way to force a check on the one s that have been already submitted . i do not want to mislead anyone but what I also noticed is that the date format between the two report looks different US format for the activity completion and Italian format for the course completion. My (not so) educated guess is that one reads the server timings and the other one the user PC timings if this is the case how could i solve it?.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have a similar problem to yours, in my case, the users completed the course weeks ago, however, the LMS decided to update all the completion times and now all activities and course completion time in the "Course completion report" do not match. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=432911 Regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Changing the cron scheduling to 5 minutes actually solved the issue for us, the new students who taken the course were tracked properly with of course 5 minutes of timing resolution that is acceptable for us even if we still need to find a way fix old attempts ( i am aware this might not be possible). Basically to my understanding the activity progress is instantaneous while the completion runs at scheduled intervals. That 's why i saw the same timing in the completion reports on most of the activity they actually match the previous settings and actually we did not notice that the cron was not running before the first settings tweak. Our systems runs on MariaDB .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Exactly so. Cron sets the course completion times when it runs its process. Another important thing to remember is that if a Teacher unlocks the course completions for any reason, usually to change the completion criteria, then all the previous completion times for the users are deleted. When cron runs next, it will recalculate those completions and give all those users NEW completion times. This new time may be days, months, or even years after the time the user actually completed the course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, To your question about erase/reset completion data for a student, I think there is no easy way to do this other than modifying the database directly. You may want to take a look at this -> https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=369001 Regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: If all you need to do is reset activity completion dates or some of the manual settings in the course completion (eg Manual approval by role), any teacher can do that in the Activity completion report or in the Course completion report, respectively. Just un check the varioius activity completion box. If you need to do more than that, such as reset other criteria, there is currently not an easy way to do that. The Course Recompletion plugin that Adolfo mentions is excellent, but it is based on a schedule and only works on users that have completed the course already, so that they could retake it with a clean slate. You can't manually choose which user's completion data to delete using it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: By the way, what I have said here is only one particular use case. Actually, the course completion calculates do often try to save the times according to one of the criteria for the course completion, including grabbing the latest activity completion. If you are using only activity completion criteria, it usually does this - from what I have seen. So, sometimes the course completion data is the same as the most recent activity completion date. But there's a lot of other possible criteria too. It saves most of those times in a special table for things that otherwise don't have dates (course_completion_crit_comp). Exactly which dates it grabs for this this and when it uses the cron time, it a bit of a mystery as Adolfo says above. If someone figures it all out, I hope they post it here.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Also, if you have SQL Reporting ability you can use some of the queries I have in the Ad-hoc reports page which show the details for user activity completions including the exact times for each activity: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#User_activity_completions_with_dates

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know, and I could be wrong, the activity completion will be set at the date/time the actual activity was completed. The course completion is set at the date /time the cron job ran, and evaluated the student's activity completions as meeting the course completion criteria. Therefore, the activities may complete at different times to the course, and if Cron is running every ten minutes or so then it will be later than the activity completion settings by around that time. However, it could be very different if the completion criteria has been adjusted manually - unlocked, and reset, for example. In this case, the course completion will be evaluated once you've saved the new settings, and all the data relating to completions prior to that will be lost (in the course completion, at least). The activity completion data will not change, so you could end up with all activities completing way before the course is complete, if the course completion was later unlocked and changed. If you do not unlock course completion and it is not showing a date/time close to when all activities or requirements are met, then check your Cron jobs. It's possible that Cron is set to run at a different time to the default, or that it is not running at all...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: difference in timing in completion reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Hal, I do think you are right in all you mentioned, in my case, the course completion was not changed and the cron job is running every 1 minute. We have seen this problem when we have courses with a large number of users (+5000). For far it has happened twice and we do not know why. I opened this thread -> https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=432979 Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Share your experience about Moodle Analytics models

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-Hoc Reports Not Sending eMails
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you putting in the username in "Automatically email to" field? When Robert says "I've also tried using various emails addresses," that may be the problem. You can only put the username of the user in Moodle here, not the email address, or it will not work. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-Hoc Reports Not Sending eMails
ResponsesInList.Text: This is because the permission is set to "Anyone who can view this report (report/customviewsql:view). That list by default is only the admins and managers, so it limits the users you can choose to email based on who has that permission set in your system. As the documentation says: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Custom_SQL_queries_report#List_of_available_queries

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-Hoc Reports Not Sending eMails
ResponsesInList.Text: You can see how often the task runs by going to Site admin > Server > Scheduled tasks and looking for the "Ad-hoc database queries: run scheduled reports task" - that's how you control how often it runs. By default this is once an hour. When a particular report runs is based on time you set for each report (but will be executed only by the task above on its schedule). But the daily, weekly, and monthly settings are fixed to run only on their particular schedule: every day, the first day of the week based on your system locale and the first of the month.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, if you can execute the query. Coursid has to be replace by your id and if you use mysql / mariadb the function array_agg must be replace by group_concat Hope it's help. Dominique.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Dominique. Thanks for the reply. "...i don't know what is the class enrollment status..." - See image... Ricardo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, sorry for my question it was obvious. I realize it after... SELECT firstname ,lastname ,username ,t2.grp -- ,decode(t3.status, '0','Active','Inactive') -- my sql /mariadb ,CASE t3.status WHEN 0 THEN 'active' WHEN 1 THEN 'inactive' END FROM (SELECT t1.id ,t1.firstname ,t1.lastname ,t1.username FROM mdl_user t1 ,(SELECT userid, instanceid FROM mdl_role_assignments t1 LEFT JOIN mdl_context t2 ON t1.contextid = t2.id AND t1.roleid = 5) t2 ,mdl_course t3 WHERE t1.id = t2.userid AND t3.id = t2.instanceid AND t3.id = 4979 ORDER BY lastname) t1 LEFT JOIN (SELECT t2.userid, array_agg (t1.name) grp FROM mdl_groups t1,mdl_groups_members t2 WHERE t1.id=t2.groupid AND courseid= 4979 GROUP BY courseid, userid) t2¬† ON t1.id = t2.userid LEFT JOIN (SELECT userid, t1.status from mdl_user_enrolments t1, mdl_enrol t2 WHERE t1.enrolid = t2.id AND courseid= 4979 ) t3 ON t1.id = t3.userid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Dominique, I'm using "Configurable reports" block and you query works like a charm! Thanks! The only column that would be missing is "Status". I would be grateful if you could help me. All the best, Ricardo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ricardo, In the second query I sent the status was in it (but I forgot to name the column). If you need more info don't hesitate to ask. Dominique. SELECT firstname ,lastname ,username ,t2.grp --¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† , decode(t3.status, '0','Active','Inactive') as status -- mysql/mariadb , CASE t3.status WHEN 0 THEN 'active' WHEN 1 THEN 'inactive' END as status FROM (SELECT t1.id ,t1.firstname ,t1.lastname ,t1.username FROM mdl_user t1 ,(SELECT userid, instanceid FROM mdl_role_assignments t1 LEFT JOIN mdl_context t2 ON t1.contextid = t2.id AND t1.roleid = 5) t2 ,mdl_course t3 WHERE t1.id = t2.userid AND t3.id = t2.instanceid AND t3.id = 4979 ORDER BY lastname) t1 LEFT JOIN (SELECT t2.userid, array_agg(t1.name) grp FROM mdl_groups t1,mdl_groups_members t2 WHERE t1.id=t2.groupid AND courseid=4979 GROUP BY courseid, userid) t2¬† ON t1.id = t2.userid LEFT JOIN (SELECT userid, t1.status from mdl_user_enrolments t1, mdl_enrol t2 WHERE t1.enrolid = t2.id AND courseid=4979) t3 ON t1.id = t3.userid

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Report with "firstname, username, class enrollment status and group"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Dominique, And again it works like a charm! Thanks again! I just had to remove the line ",decode(t3.status, '0','Active','Inactive') as status -- mysql/mariadb" as i'm using PostgreSQL . Thanks again! Ricardo

ResponsesInList.Title: Swapped Student Names & Activity Name Headers on Activity Completion Report 3.9
Re: Swapped Student Names & Activity Name Headers on Activity Completion Report 3.9
ResponsesInList.Text: John, This is pure gold! The report should have been like this from the start. I am however, getting this error in Boost on 3.9: "SCSS code is not valid, fails with: parse error: failed at `flex-flow; row;} ` (stdin) on line 2, at column 71." I think it's just a typo with semi-colon for a colon. It parses okay and works great with this instead: `#page-report-progress-index table#completion-progress {display: flex; flex-flow: row;}` This also works in 4.0 Boost as well as 3.9 (see screenshot), although it does clip off the icon at the beginning of each row (former column). That seems to be the only difference between the report in 4.0 and earlier. To fix the 4.0 clipping, if I set the margin-left to -42, it leaves out the icon on the row altogether: `#page-report-progress-index .modicon {padding-top: 5px; margin-left: -42px;}` or even betterL `#page-report-progress-index .modicon {display: none;}` I'm sure it can be tweaked to include the whole icon, but hiding it works for me. Very nice !!

ResponsesInList.Title: Analytics installed in a separate server - Two Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Analytics installed in a separate server - Two Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Ideally yes, you would create a separate account for each moodle so that one Moodle site can't access a model from another Moodle site accidentally or maliciously. but.... practically the models are uniquely identified based on the site url so you shouldn't hit any collisions - here's the relevant part in the code that it uses to identify a model: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/analytics/classes/model.php#L1557

ResponsesInList.Title: Modify Ad-Hoc db Query to include a specific date range
ResponsesInList.Text:
Downloaded the ad-hoc contributed reports plugin Added 2.6.2 Site-Wide Grade Report with Just Course Totals query Tested and ran a successful query with the Query SQL listed in Moodle Docs However, I want to just have the site wide course totals that were completed this month (from beginning of month to whatever the current day is that I run the report near the end of the month). I tried looking up the MySQL code for a date range in Moodle Docs, was unsuccessful Searched:¬†dev.mysql.com/doc/ , stackoverflow , and github , but I didn't understand as I'm not a coder The code I found that seems like it would perform the function I am looking for is: BETWEEN DATE_FORMAT(NOW() - INTERVAL 1 MONTH, '%Y-%m-01 00:00:00') AND DATE_FORMAT(LAST_DAY(NOW() - INTERVAL 1 MONTH), '%Y-%m-%d 23:59:59') But I don' know if that is the right instruction or format or anything. What could I add to the listed code that would just have the totals for the specific date range I mentioned? 
```text
SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', u.firstname + ' ' + u.lastname AS 'Display Name',
cc.name AS 'Category',
CASE
  WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course'
   THEN c.fullname + ' Course Total'
  ELSE gi.itemname
END AS 'Item Name',

ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Grade,
DATEADD(ss,gg.timemodified,'1970-01-01') AS Time

FROM prefix_course AS c
JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid
JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id
JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid
JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id
JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid
JOIN prefix_course_categories as cc ON cc.id = c.category

WHERE  gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'course'

ORDER BY lastname
```
 Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify Ad-Hoc db Query to include a specific date range
ResponsesInList.Text: The only item of data in the query that is date related is gg.timemodified, the time of the grading. So, you need to add your data limitation logic to your WHERE clause to get the gg.timemodified that is in this same month. However, you don't need any of the formatting to due the date calculation at all because you are not showing them to the user in the report results: just do the straight comparison. One good way to do this is explained here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11808232/how-do-i-select-between-the-1st-day-of-the-current-month-and-current-day-in-mysq . Remember, all dates and times in Moodle are saved as timestamps. It is better and quicker to do the math on the timestamps themselves instead of having to convert them to some format or another when you can.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify Ad-Hoc db Query to include a specific date range
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, I updated the WHERE clause to: WHERE FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified) between DATE_FORMAT(NOW() ,'%Y-%m-01') AND NOW() AND gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'course'

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify Ad-Hoc db Query to include a specific date range
ResponsesInList.Text: That's a very cool trick with the formatting DATE_FORMAT(NOW() ,'%Y-%m-01')

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify Ad-Hoc db Query to include a specific date range
ResponsesInList.Text: Also, my director asked me to get weekly reporting, and I just wanted to add what worked for me after looking at this post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22769986/how-to-get-last-week-date-range-based-on-current-date-in-sql This code worked for me: SELECT u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', CONCAT(username) AS 'Display Name', c.fullname AS 'Course', cc.name AS 'Category', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'course' THEN CONCAT(c.fullname, ' - Total') ELSE gi.itemname END AS 'Item Name', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Grade, FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified) AS TIME FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc ON cc.id = c.category WHERE FROM_UNIXTIME(gg.timemodified) between DATE_ADD(CURDATE(), INTERVAL -(5 + dayofweek(CURDATE())) DAY) and DATE_ADD(CURDATE(), INTERVAL -(dayofweek(CURDATE()) - 1) DAY) AND gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'course' ORDER BY lastname

ResponsesInList.Title: Participation Report with Quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: We have been using the Participation report for many years with a variety of activity types. Our teachers use it to bulk contact students who have not completed a particular activity. When using the participation report for a quiz and selecting 'Post' for actions, We assumed that "No" meant students have not completed the quiz and 'Yes' meant that they have completed it. Recently I have noticed our assumptions are incorrect. I ran some tests. "No" means they have not yet viewed the quiz. 'Yes (1)' seems to show that they have viewed a quiz, 'Yes (2)' means they have viewed and attempted it, while 'Yes (3)' shows they have completed the quiz. Higher numbers, like 'Yes (5)' and 'Yes (7)' seem to show that students have completed multiple attempts. It seems like a variety of actions count as posts.¬†Can anyone confirm the same experience?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to calculate the Moodle's prediction models?
ResponsesInList.Text: right - so first you need to read that doc linked above - and see how each activity is broken down into cognitive and social indicators - how those indicators are calculated is covered at a high level in that doc. Each activity in moodle defines it's own indicator classes eg here's the social breadth one for the forum activity: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/forum/classes/analytics/indicator/social_breadth.php Which basically uses the community of inquiry class here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/analytics/classes/local/indicator/community_of_inquiry_activity.php The values calculated by Moodle for these indicators are stored in the mdl_analytics_indicator_calc table and then collected to be sent to the machine learning mode - to understand the indicator_calc table data you should also understand Moodle's " context " concept so that you can match the records in this table to a user.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi everyone, can anyone help me figure out how to pivot data in an Ad Hoc report's SQL query? The examples of pivot statements available online seem straightforward enough, but I'm not able to make it fit my current use case. Here's what I'm attempting to do My query so far is: 
```text
SELECT <fields>¬†
FROM {user} u INNER JOIN {course_completions} cc ON u.id = cc.userid
INNER JOIN {course} c ON c.id = cc.course¬†
WHERE c.id in (330, 442)
```
 This gives me a list of every user completion on these specific two courses. Now, I'd like to have the Activity/Module completions (mdl_course_modules and mdl_course_modules_completion) but a JOIN would just create like 10+ rows where I want just one. What I want to do is pivot the data from these two tables, and have it appear as columns, so that each module completion has its own column, and one user's course completion is limited to one row.
Does anyone have any leads on how to do this, or a simple example of pivoting those tables to match my needs? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text: One way to do it is using the function GROUP_CONCAT. You can find some examples of that in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page if you search the page. But if you have a lot of data to put into a single column, it can become unwieldy pretty quickly. I use this method if there are only a few things to put into the column. Otherwise, I export the full data and then do pivots in a spreadsheet.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text: This works I'd love to have it split up between columns, as a pivot would do (and my use case makes it more helpful to pivot it before export, since the end user might not know how to), but for now this is perfectly usable. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text: Vedant, Most welcome. Also, if using GROUP_CONCAT be aware that the default size for it is small, only 1024 bytes. You may need more room for the combined text. See this discussion on that issue and how to solve it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll definitely have a look at that, thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text:
For anyone reading this forum discussion afterwards, here's what I ended up doing 
```text
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1000 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 1",
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1709 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Chapter 2 E-learning",
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1234 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 2",
```
 
```text
    ...
```
 
```text
    GROUP BY u.id, c.id
```
 Where: m.id is the ID of a module you want to track in each column mc.completionstate is the completionstate of that module for a specific user, ie the data that goes under each column The string at the end is the column name desired u.id is the user id c.id is the course id The results are as follows: user id other user or course info quiz chapter 1 chapter 2 e-learning quiz chapter 2 200 ... 2 1 2 Just as a note, null & 0 is incomplete, 1 is complete, 2 is complete&passed, 3 is complete&failed. Check the moodle schema docs for more info if needed

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
ResponsesInList.Text: Firstly, yes, this report isn't entirely scalable. We'd need to go in and manually find the new module numbers and add them in. However I do prefer this to any of the previous solutions I've investigated, but I'm open to hearing if there's any better ones. Secondly, I'm not an sql expert by any means, but I do believe that the PIVOT function is supposed to aggregate items, such as the sum or count of certain values (as opposed to this, which is just listing one value, if that makes sense) And finally, we could definitely pivot using Power BI or Excel, that would work. But this report also has the benefit of being readable if one of our instructors needs to go in and check on anything. Ultimately though I think the question of which approach is better would vary. Maybe exporting a list of module completions separately and manipulating it in your end software would work better for you. Cheers!

ResponsesInList.Title: Analytics -- the option to receive emails or not
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all We enabled analytics for this first time (after reading the documentation and watching the explanatory video) and hundreds of our teachers were flooded with collectively >1,000 insight emails. Clearly, this is not ideal. The concept of analytics is a good one. However, there needs to be options and control over how these insights are gathered and distributed. For example, in one circumstance, I may desire site administrators to manually view insights reports periodically. In other circumstances, I may choose that teachers receive email notifications for given models. A blanket "email every teacher in every circumstance", with no ability to set this preference against each model is a poorly conceived approach, and has led to us needing to disable the whole thing. This is a shame as we are missing out on useful information. Please consider introducing emails as an *option* for analytics. Kind Regards Lee Cujes

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Analytics -- the option to receive emails or not
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee, On this page: Site administration ‚Üí Messaging ‚Üí (Default) Notification settings You have the following notification setting: "Insights generated by prediction models" You can change the defaults and make it an "Opt in" thing - setting the default so users won't get notifications with insights, and if a user wants such insights, he can set its own notification settings in the preferences.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Analytics -- the option to receive emails or not
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Acqua, that's the setting we were looking for. For future enhancements to Analytics, it would be good if within the Analytics settings page itself, it referenced (or directly accessed) this email setting.

ResponsesInList.Title: Getting reports needed on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, We are hosted Moodlecloud users and I'm stuck trying to get the information I need using the reports available. Background Info: We have a number of courses¬† in which the assessment for each topic within the course is a quiz made up of 30 -60 essay questions (quiz).¬† Usually 14 - 15 quizzes across the course.¬† The quizzes are manually graded by the trainers. The students can attempt each quiz as many times as needed.¬† The quiz settings are set so that when they start a new attempt their previous answers are brought into the new attempt. Each course has up to five trainers with specific students assigned to their group. Reporting Requirement: For each course, I need to do a report that shows something like this but accurately shows the number of quiz attempts graded. What reports I've tried and the issue: - Individual quiz report - can show me this but topic (unit) but it would mean having lookup formulas to group the students under their trainer.¬† it would also mean running the report for each quiz separately - which would also be very time consuming - Activity Completion - only shows when it was completed (graded as a pass) - Course Logs exported to excel Adjusting the date so it is date format not text and using that to extract monthly data Using the 'Event Name' column to count instances of 'quiz attempt submitted' - this works great for the submissions Using the 'Event Name' column to count instances of 'user graded' - this doesn't work as it overinflates the number (see image above). I've worked out that 'user graded' includes partially graded quizzes (i.e. the trainer graded part of the quiz, left it and then came back and finished grading it) Using the 'Event Name' column to count instances of 'Course activity completion updated' - It only counts when the quiz was graded as a pass - not when it was graded and needed to be done again. What I need help with? I need a report that shows how many quiz attempts have been graded by each trainer and I need to be able to split this into months.¬† It would be good if it showed the quiz name in the report as in the future we might want to be able to drill further and show this information as well. Does anyone know how I can accurately get this information from a course hosted on Moodlecloud in a user-friendly way (i.e. so I don't have to pull things from various reports' Thanks for any help/suggestions. Michelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Ad hoc reports: How to define and use a function when the CREATE keyword is disallowed?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi all, I've got a query in which I have a repeating pattern, like so: 
```text
MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1000 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 1",
MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1709 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Chapter 2 E-learning",
MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1500 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 2",
```
 Now with each mc.completionstate I need to do a switch case such that if it's 0 it's labelled "Incomplete", if it's 1 it's labelled "Complete", etc. I could just put that in each line but I'll be duplicating the code 10+ times. I thought about writing a custom function, but the problem is that the CREATE keyword is disallowed in the Ad hoc reports section, so I can't do that as far as I know. When I try creating a function: So how exactly would I go about doing this, does anyone have any ideas?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: How to define and use a function when the CREATE keyword is disallowed?
ResponsesInList.Text: The code in the Ad-hoc plugin has a "bad words list" : 'ALTER', 'CREATE', 'DELETE', 'DROP', 'GRANT', 'INSERT', 'INTO', 'TRUNCATE', 'UPDATE'. So, the only way around this issue is to edit the code (which is in localib.php). The Config Reports plugin, on the other hand, does have a setting for " SQL Security" in the block settings that can allow certain keywords for inserting data: INSERT, INTO, CREATE seem to be looked for (in report.class.php). That may work for you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: How to define and use a function when the CREATE keyword is disallowed?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Randy! I'll investigate further and get back to you if I have any questions

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad hoc reports: How to define and use a function when the CREATE keyword is disallowed?
ResponsesInList.Text: customsql is great for creating plain SQL reports. But if you're after something more complicated, why don't you create your own report plugin. That way you can free yourself up from the constraints of trying to cram everything into a single query.

ResponsesInList.Title: Logs = prior to six months ago?
ResponsesInList.Text: We have a course taught in the Spring of 2021 (which hasn't been touched since then). I need to retrieve some data regarding one student with a late grade dispute, but the reports options in Moodle only retrieve data from the last six months. Is there a way to go back further? I have a course backup from June 2021; if I restore that backup, would I get the historical course reports? Thanks in advance for any insight... Lisa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Logs = prior to six months ago?
ResponsesInList.Text: When you say the "report option in Moodle only retrieves data from the last six months" do you mean that your site is set to truncate the logs after 6 months? (In Site admin > Plugins > Logging > Standard logs :: Keep logs for. ). If so then that makes sense as you would only see the last six months of dates in the pull down menu in Reports > Logs to choose a date. If that is what is happening, then that old data is no longer in the database . If you did a course backup and you checked the "Include course logs" option, then when you restore the course it will restore all those log entries as well with their original dates and times. (If the backup did not include those course logs, then there are no old logs to restore.) _However_, the very next time the site runs the task to truncate the logs older than 6 months, it will then delete all those restored entries with those dates older than 6 months. By default his task runs once a day. So, if you need to view those old dates for a while, then you might consider temporarily setting the Logs not to delete, until you can get that old data out and save it, then set it back to truncate at 6 months.

ResponsesInList.Title: Log reports frequently "The user with id 'X' changed the password of the user with id 'X'. (Workaround found)
ResponsesInList.Text: After bulk importing a user list I found the logfile full of messages: 1850 of this type in under a day. My research led to the following: Accidently two user were created where both Mail addresses contained a german character, the sz (·∫û) symbol. Whereas I am confident that the creation with "umlaut" (e.g. ae, √§) failed at import the sz got through. After disabling a user the reporting stopped immediately. I deleted the users and created them new with their correct address and everything is fine. Maybe theses other entries are related: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=409685 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=410752 Best Bernhard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting Moodle Log to excel error

First, I found this article. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=338364 I set the site Debugging mode and downloaded the csv file. In a downloaded file, I could read something like this. Allowed memory size of 536870912 bytes exhausted (tried to allocate 112385280 bytes) in xxxxxxx/lib/dml/mysqli_native_moodle_database.php Mine was gradebook result anyway, and I see the course size is above 1.2G or some. My memory_limit of php.ini was just 128M, so I set it to 2048M. I reloaded httpd and php-fpm. Now I could download the whole grades as a csv file. Great!

ResponsesInList.Title: Configurable report - Users who have not attempted a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I do realise there was another discussion on this from 2017 but it is locked and unable to add to the post. Apologies in advance I am new to this community As per the above, I am wanting to write a configurable report that shows only users that have not attempted the quiz. Below is the SQL I have put together to try and get what I am after. If anyone could offer me some assistance would be greatly appreciated. Code below so far ----- Select c.id AS "Course ID", c.fullname AS "Course Name", cm.id as "Quiz ID", q.name AS "Quiz Name", u.idnumber AS "User ID", CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS "User's name", ss.attempt AS "Attempt" FROM prefix_quiz q INNER JOIN prefix_course c ON q.course = c.id INNER JOIN prefix_course_categories cc ON c.category = cc.id INNER JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.instance = q.id and cm.module = 16 INNER JOIN prefix_enrol e ON e.courseid = c.id INNER JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue on ue.enrolid = e.id INNER JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = ue.userid FULL OUTER JOIN prefix_scorm_aicc_session ss ON ss.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN prefix_scorm s ON s.course = c.id where c.fullname = 'FIT1051 2021 Sem 2 (Australia)' GROUP BY c.id, c.fullname, cm.id, q.name, u.id, u.firstname, u.lastname, ss.attempt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable report - Users who have not attempted a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are looking for users who have not yet attempted a quiz, then you will need to look into the quiz_attempts table - which will show you who _has_ attempted the quiz. From there, you will need to deduce the enroled users who have no such attempts in the table. Or, to put it another way, you want all the enroled users in the course who have no entry in the quiz_attempts table. Some of the queries on the Ad-hoc contributed reports page may help you out, such as this one https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#List_the_users_that_did_not_take_the_Quiz or this one https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Student_responses_.28answers.29_to_quiz_questions . I don't understand why your query references the scorm tables, which not related to quizzes in any way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable report - Users who have not attempted a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy, Really appreciate you replying to my thread

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Configurable report - Users who have not attempted a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text:
I think the issue is probably the location of the closing parens in the second where clause in the sub select. It seems to be out of place and close the sub select too early. That's probably why it worked with the original code okay. When troubleshooting such issues I try to reduce the query to the absolute basics. In this case, I would remove all the category parts and just put in a simple course id to a course that I can manually verify and check the results against. So, just a c.id= will let me check that. Note also that, with more than one course, this query will return only users who have no quizzes in any courses, so they many have done one quiz in one course but not in the others. Also, it returns all enrolled roles, so both teachers and students, since it is just looking at enrolments and not at role assignments. (You can always add that in later.) The following stripped down one works for me and shows the logic of the query more clearly: 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT


c.fullname AS "Course Name",


u2.username AS "User"




FROM prefix_user_enrolments ue


JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON e.id = ue.enrolid


JOIN prefix_course AS c ON c.id = e.courseid


JOIN prefix_user AS u2 ON u2.id = ue.userid


WHERE c.id = 2


AND ue.userid NOT IN 


¬†(SELECT qa.userid


¬† FROM prefix_quiz_attempts AS qa


¬† JOIN prefix_quiz AS q ON qa.quiz = q.id


¬† JOIN prefix_course c on q.course = c.id


¬† WHERE c.id = 2)


¬† 


ORDER BY c.fullname, u2.username
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Only show certain activities on course completion report for the teacher

There are two reports - a report for Activity completion and a report for course completion as in the Course completion status block You can indicate activity completion for all activities students need to do but you can select only the ones they have to do that count towards their final grade by selecting them for course completion - and then only those will appear in the course completion report for example in the Course completion status block . ResponsesInList.Title: Ad-hoc database queries: Display assignment feedback as HTML
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Moodlers, I would really appreciate some helps to be able displaying assignment feedback comment as HTML, as the current result display all HTML Tag as the outcomes. The SQL code used as the following: 
```text
SELECT


CONCAT(u.firstname,' ',u.lastname) AS Student,


c.fullname AS Course_Name,¬†


a.name AS Assignment_Name,


DATE_FORMAT(CONVERT_TZ(FROM_UNIXTIME(ag.timemodified),'+00:00','+10:00'),'%d-%M-%Y') AS Assignment_Date,


IF (ag.grade=2,'C','NYC') as Assignment_Result,


CONCAT(ug.firstname,' ',ug.lastname) AS Assessor,


afc.commenttext AS Comment,


afc.commentformat AS Comment_Format


FROM prefix_course AS c


JOIN prefix_assign AS a ON a.course = c.id


JOIN prefix_assign_grades AS ag ON ag.assignment = a.id


JOIN prefix_assignfeedback_comments AS afc ON afc.grade= ag.id
```
 And the outcome is displayed as the following It will be reader friendly if the Comment can be displayed in the HTML form so all the tags will help to format the comment. Thank you Regards, Riady

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ad-hoc database queries: Display assignment feedback as HTML
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know this is not possible in the Ad-hoc database queries plugin. It treats any html tags as normal text. You could try to use the Configurable Reports plugin to do this sort of thing. It does allow some basic tags. You will probably have to take that column apart with some SQL to get exactly what you want (eg make the links work).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: course administration > course completion menu item
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you tried setting Course " View course completion report" (report/completion:view ) to Prohibit? It is set to Allow by default for Manager, Teacher, and Non-editing Teacher roles.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: course administration > course completion menu item
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah, well, I don't know if there is a way to block the access specifically to the Course admin > Course completion. It seems to be included in the permission for Update course (moodle/course:update). The two tabs for the activities are controlled by the permission /course:manageactivities. In /course/completion.php it checks for both of these: if the user does not have course update but does have the ability to manageactivities, it will redirect them and let them see those two tabs for the bulk and default activities, otherwise they see and can set all three. It only blocks it if the user lacks both those permissions. So, it seems if the user has either those permissions, they can see the Course Completion menu.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Forum Analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! Just brainstorming here: The Moodle Association of Japan moved the reporting about forums forward via the MUA a few release cycles ago. Now, uses have access to a "Summary Report" and users can also "Export" raw forum data for analysis. These are two positives. However, working with these tools and other forum analysis tools, we have discovered things really bog down when the data grows big. Checking relationships between replies (for example) and calculating the depth of replies (for another example) for each user, each group, each grouping , and even analyzing "discussion post by discussion post" gets increasingly complex and taxing on system resources. Would there be any value or benefit in designing (for Moodle) a kind of "Report Caching" system that would periodically update selected tables with summarized data for display? What I mean is that a user chooses the report they want to "cache" and then that report gets run using the specified criteria once every cron cycle (as a scheduled task -- for example -- hourly). Then the data is slowly populated in the background and made available through a single table read and display when the user accesses the report. If there already exists such a system (I'm not talking about configurable reports which require regular users to have a deeper knowledge of SQL ), I'd be interested in learning more about it. If such a system doesn't exist, I suggest (with LA becoming more and more prominent) that Moodle should begin planning one. What do others think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Total Course Logs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I use Course Logs very often for monthly reports and it would be handy to download the logs for every course at once with a "course name" column or such (filtered by the current month), save having to individually download every course log every month. Is there any possible way to do this via configurable reports? I'm not new to SQL but I can't find any table or relationship pertaining to the course logs. Diolch (Thank you)!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Total Course Logs
ResponsesInList.Text: There is no separate table for that. All logs are in the main table mdl_logstore_standard_log which has a column for course called courseid. All you need to do is filter on that column to limit it to specific courses. You will find several examples of how to use this in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page, eg https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Total_activity_per_course.2C_per_unique_user_on_the_last_24h .

ResponsesInList.Title: SQL recommended trainings
ResponsesInList.Text: Does anyone have online SQL training that they recommend, especially if it is specific for Moodle? I am an amateur when it comes to SQL, but would like to be better able to create and edit¬†Ad-hoc database queries and¬†Configurable Reports. Thanks for any recommendations you could give.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQL recommended trainings
ResponsesInList.Text: Funny you should ask this ... was attempting to use some shared queries for the adhoc tool and was having issues. What came to my mind was an admin tool that could be turned on and off for 'show query' for some standard moodle reports .¬† But that's a feature request which would require votes and concensus to get into core.¬†¬† (probably will never happen).¬†¬† So ... sometimes one can do 'monkey see, monkey do' to get there - with some minor additions.¬† Trick, of course, is to figure out those seemingly 'minor additions'. :| For beginning and maybe future use, if you have control of your mysql server config, consider turning on General Query Log. Shared info (while below shows the slow query log as well, to begin don't do that one ... just the general query log ... and not for very long as logs will build up in a hurry - get large - and slow down your site ... we don't want to have 'un-intended site consequences'. General Query Log, but having it written to a flat file would remove a lot of possibilities for flexibility of displaying, especially in real-time. If you just want a simple, easy-to-implement way to see what's going on though, enabling the GQL and then using running tail -f on the logfile would do the trick. https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/query-log.html one could setup mysql to log, have mysql log queries, then tell mysql to turn off logging.¬†¬† What ever is done when logging is on is seen in logs. Don't leave it on or those could easily fill up a lot of space on DB server. Settings in my.cnf # for logging general_log_file=/var/log/mysql/mysql-general.log Above multitail would show the logs as well as web server access and error log.¬†¬† You adjust to your log files locations and names. # to turn off # set global slow_query_log = 0 # set global log_slow_queries = 0 # set global log = 0; Once off, those logs can be copied out of /var/log/mysql/ saved as a text file (they are ascii anyway), download them and inspect with notepad/textedit or any text editor 'SoS', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Added columns from filter form not in download
ResponsesInList.Text:
Ok, so in my report index.php file I call my options form,
then I have this code: // Define variables. if ($id) { $report =
$DB->get_record('local_customreports', array('id' => $id)); $toform = new
StdClass(); $queryparams =
unserialize($report->queryparams); foreach
($queryparams as $param => $value) { $toform->{$param} = $value; } $courseids =
$queryparams['course']; $requestedcohort =
$queryparams['cohort']; $completionstatus
= $queryparams['completionstatus']; $datefrom =
$queryparams['datefrom']; $dateto =
$queryparams['dateto']; if
(!empty($queryparams['coloptions'])) { $profieldids =
array_keys($queryparams['coloptions']); } $cachedata = ''; $mform->set_data($toform); } else { $cache = cache::make_from_params(cache_store::MODE_SESSION,
'report_trainingsummary', 'search'); if ($cachedata =
$cache->get('data')) { // Cache form
submission so that it is preserved while paging through the report. $mform->set_data($cachedata); } } // Form has been submitted or we have cached data. $data = ($mform->is_submitted() ? $mform->get_data() :
fullclone($cachedata)); if ($data) { if
(!empty($data->course)) { $courseids =
$data->course; } if
(!empty($data->cohort)) { $requestedcohort =
$data->cohort; } if
(!empty($data->completionstatus)) { $completionstatus
= $data->completionstatus; } if
(!empty($data->datefrom)) { $datefrom =
$data->datefrom; } if
(!empty($data->dateto)) { $dateto =
$data->dateto; } if
(!empty($data->coloptions)) { $profieldids =
array_keys($data->coloptions); } unset($data->submitbutton); $cache->set('data', $data); } Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Completed course report
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to generate a report and later have the user autogenerate within the course and download as CSV, a list of users that have completed a course given it's short name and date of completion. If there isn't an easy way out of the box, does anyone have a similar SQL query I can run?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Completed course report
ResponsesInList.Text: I created this query to test: SELECT dbo.mdl_user.username, dbo.mdl_user_info_data.data AS EmployeeNum, dbo.mdl_user.firstname, dbo.mdl_user.lastname, dbo.mdl_course.shortname, dbo.mdl_course.fullname, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timeenrolled, '1970-01-01') AS EnrolledDate, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timestarted, '1970-01-01') AS StartedDate, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timecompleted, '1970-01-01') AS CompletedDate FROM dbo.mdl_user_info_data RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_user ON dbo.mdl_user_info_data.userid = dbo.mdl_user.id RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_course RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_course_completions ON dbo.mdl_course.id = dbo.mdl_course_completions.course ON dbo.mdl_user.id = dbo.mdl_course_completions.userid WHERE (dbo.mdl_course_completions.timecompleted IS NOT NULL) AND (dbo.mdl_user_info_data.fieldid = 1)

ResponsesInList.Title: Unwanted insights emails from hidden courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Teachers are complaining about receiving insights emails from hidden courses via the "Students who have not accessed the course recently" analytics model. We have many instances of hidden courses with students enrolments. This is a deliberate choice, not a mistake, as many Teachers make use of meta-link enrolments and teach courses that draw enrolments from these hidden courses. Is there a way we can stop models from generating insights for hidden courses? I see that hidden courses are not included in the "Students at risk of dropping out" model, but it does not appear to be the case for the "not accessed" models. Or have I missed something here?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unwanted insights emails from hidden courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Heli for your comment. I think you're right and you found a bug. Hidden courses were added to 'Invalid site element' list in MDL-66806 that affects "Students at risk of dropping out" and some other models, but not "Students who have not accessed the course recently" model. So I've created MDL-71274 issue to fix it. I encourage you to watch, vote or comment on it to add as many information as you can. Thanks for your help and support!

ResponsesInList.Title: Activities assigned to specific groups
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to write a sql query that shows activities that have been assigned to specific groups.¬† Where are these group assignments stored?¬† I can see how a particular course gets assigned to a group(s), but not a particular activity.¬† (We primarily use Questionnaires).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activities assigned to specific groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Katie Activities are not assigned groups specifically. If you set them to use Groups in their settings, either Separate or Visible, they simply uses the groups as defined at the course level. (Except Assignment, which is something else.) You will find the group settings for each activity in the course_modules table. Now, if you are using Access restrictions to restrict an activity to a specific group, then that is also in the course_modules table in the column called "availability". Unfortunately, it is a mess: it is not properly normalized at all and so you will have to parse out the string to find the group. For example: {"op":"&","c":[{"type":"group","id":93}],"showc":[true]} which tells you this activity is restricted by group to the group with id 93.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activities assigned to specific groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Katie, Ah, are you using Config reports and/or the Ad-hoc queries plugins? Those are both read only basically, though Config Reports will let you use some basic things like UPDATE if you turn off the "SQL Security" in its plugin settings. But it can't create things like views or temp tables and so forth. However, if you create views another way, you can certainly use those in your queries, as long as the views are in the same moodle db (because the plugins run as the Moodle user set up for that db and that should be the only one it has access to.). A common and useful view is one for user firstname and lastname. I usually do one for course completions because its a popular request. Also, if your find yourself having to do reports from the logs, a view can dramatically speed things up, for instance if you have to do a query for "last time a student entered their courses". If you are new to Moodle then perhaps these things may help: - Do you have Adminer installed? https://moodle.org/plugins/local_adminer . Everyone has their favorite tools, but this one is very handy because it is right there in Moodle. - I assume you are aware of the Ad-hoc contributed queries page: https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports but if not, it's a mismash but I borrow from it all the time. - Finally, most of the questions about queries are posted over in the forum for the Configurable Reports plugin rather than here, mostly because of history I suppose, but most of the SQL people hang out there: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=7979 Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Grades for all user and for all courses placed horizontally
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Colleagues, I saw many of custom SQL -query reports developed in/for Configurable Reports plugin (and even modified some of them for own purposes) but they always lists courses vertically, e.g. if we want to get all final grades for each course a specific user enrolled then report lists vertically 1) userlogins and then 2) courses for each user. As a result we have a long report with repeating userlogins. But I never ever saw such report with courses placed horizontally, e.g. like this: Course1¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Course2¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†Course3¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† All passed Userlogin1¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†FinalGrade11¬† ¬† FinalGrade12¬† ¬† FInalGrade13¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†V Userlogin2¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†FinalGrade21¬† ¬† FinalGrade22¬† ¬† FInalGrade23¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†V where FinalGrade is max grade received by a user, "All passed" mark placed when FinalGrades for all Courses (Course1,2,3) are greater than threshhold (e.g. 80 out of 100). Is it possible to create such a report?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grades for all user and for all courses placed horizontally
ResponsesInList.Text:
The challenge with SQL queries is you have to pre-define the columns, but you can do that and de-duplicate using 'group by' https://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_groupby.asp If you have finite number of courses you need to report on and know the ID numbers,¬† you could build a report. A dynamic one would require something like Excel Pivot tables or another move advanced reporting package available from some Moodle partners. Below is an example pulling some additional user profile fields together and excluding based on completion data from two courses and grouping together to remove duplicates. 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT uenr.userid, u.`firstname`, u.`lastname`, u.`email`, udata.`data` AS "Type", udata2.`data` AS "Profession", udata3.`data` AS "Portal Unique ID", udata4.`data` AS "Phone Num", udata5.data AS "Postal Code",


DATE_FORMAT(CONVERT_TZ(FROM_UNIXTIME(uenr.`timecreated`),'+00:00','-05:00'), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Created Account On",


DATEDIFF(NOW(), CONVERT_TZ(FROM_UNIXTIME(uenr.`timecreated`),'+00:00','-05:00')) AS "Account age in days",


CONCAT("%%WWWROOT%%/report/outline/user.php%%Q%%id=",uenr.userid,"&course=29&mode=outline") AS "Link to English User Report",


CONCAT("%%WWWROOT%%/report/outline/user.php%%Q%%id=",uenr.userid,"&course=40&mode=outline") AS "Link to French User Report"


FROM prefix_enrol AS enr, prefix_user_enrolments AS uenr


JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = uenr.userid


JOIN prefix_user_info_data as udata ON udata.userid = u.id


JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif ON udata.fieldid = uif.id


JOIN prefix_user_info_data AS udata2 ON udata2.userid = u.id


JOIN prefix_user_info_field AS uif2 ON udata2.fieldid = uif2.id
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can one turn off "Insights" e-mails?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can one turn off "Insights" e-mails?
ResponsesInList.Text: Edward, It seems to check the capability 'tool/inspire:listinsights' when sending messages. This is set to Allow for the default Teacher, non-editing teacher and Manager roles. So leave it unset for that custom role should be enough to stop the messages. If a person has multiple conflicting roles, you may have to set it to Prevent or even Prohibit, but just unsetting it should be enough for a single system level role. Randy

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, Replying to your questions below: By default, predictive models that report insights at system or category level only notify users with¬†'moodle/analytics:listinsights' capability. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can one turn off "Insights" e-mails?
ResponsesInList.Text: We also upgraded and had a lot of teachers thinking this was spam or a fishing email. Since the 'insights' wasn't very useful for us I turned it off. This might be overkill, but here are all the steps I took. - Edited file /analytics/classes/local/target/base.php commented out line 214 that sent the email - Set permissions for all roles to 'prohibit' for 'moodle/analytics:listinsights' - To turn off for a specific user: go to user profile > Preferences > Notification preferences > turn off insights - Turned off scheduled tasks: Admin Settings > Server > Scheduled Tasks > disabled both 'Predict Models' and ' Train Models' - Disable under: Admin Settings > Analytics > Analytic Models > Actions > Disable (for both) Another issue was the email was set to come from the Site admin, so it had my name instead of the normal 'Noreply' like other emails. That caused additional confusion. After doing the above we aren't getting those emails anymore.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can one turn off "Insights" e-mails?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, Re. /report/insights/insights.php?contextid=1, contextid = 1 is the system context , the only model working at that context level is 'No teaching' (it is likely to be renamed to 'Courses at risk of not starting' in 3.8). This model reports on courses with no teachers or no student enrolments that are starting during the next week. The most likely explanation for not getting insights at that context level is that the model is disabled, another reasonable explanation is that there are no courses matching these conditions in your site. If you want to test this model you can create a new courses with start date tomorrow and with no teachers or no students. Go to site admin > analytics > analytics models and execute Get predictions (or Execute scheduled analysis in 3.8dev). You should see the course you just created in /report/insights/insights.php?contextid=1. If you want to get notifications about these insight check your notification preferences page, insights should be "on". Re. \tool_analytics\task\predict_models always failing, I can't see the error in the attached snippet. Could you paste it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Model for predicting the possibility that a student will drop out of studies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone. I open this discussion to ask if there was the possibility of having the precise model that allows us to have the probability that a student will drop out of the course of study . Specifically, I would like, eventually, to understand the scrpit that allows you to consider the different variables and the weights attributed to them. I know that moodle allows for this but I don't know if it's possible to know the model working behind that percentage. Thank you so much for your help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Model for predicting the possibility that a student will drop out of studies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Prova, That model is pretty well documented here: https://docs.moodle.org/en/Students_at_risk_of_dropping_out At a high level, each core Moodle activity provides a social and cognitive indicator. Moodle uses a target of "Enroled students show no activity in the final quarter of the course." and passes those users to the model with their associated indicators to train the Model - eg "these are the users that show behaviour we want to predict" Then it collects that data for your current users for each time-frame analysis and sends those indicators to the Machine learning engine and at the core model returns a boolean response for users that match the trained indicators.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ri: Re: Model for predicting the possibility that a student will drop out of studies
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your kind reply, Dan! But is it not possible to have exactly the model used to include all the indicators considered? The procedure is quite clear, however I really would to have the precise model used to define belonging to a certain response class. I hope for your later help! Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ri: Re: Model for predicting the possibility that a student will drop out of studies
ResponsesInList.Text: You can see this in your existing Moodle site by going to the admin > analytics > analytics models, but the default list of indicators used in the at risk of dropping out model is this list of 49 indicators: Course accessed after end date Course accessed before start date Any write action in the course Read actions amount Assignment cognitive Assignment social Book cognitive Book social Chat cognitive Chat social Choice cognitive Choice social Database cognitive Database social Feedback cognitive Feedback social Folder cognitive Folder social Forum cognitive Forum social Glossary cognitive Glossary social IMS pkg cognitive IMS pkg social Label cognitive Label social Lesson cognitive Lesson social LTI cognitive LTI social Page cognitive Page social Quiz cognitive Quiz social File cognitive File social SCORM cognitive SCORM social Survey cognitive Survey social URL cognitive URL social Wiki cognitive Wiki social Workshop cognitive Workshop social Completion tracking enabled Course potential cognitive depth Course potential social breadth

ResponsesInList.Title: Ri: Re: Ri: Re: Model for predicting the possibility that a student will drop out of studies

ResponsesInList.Title: New plugin Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD)
ResponsesInList.Text: The Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD) plugin is now available from the plugins directory ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_lord ). This plugin extracts the text content from the learning activities in a course and uses that content to compare the activities against each other, producing a similarity score between each pair of activities. The comparison uses an online sentence similarity calculator ( https://ws-nlp.vipresearch.ca/ ) to determine the similarity values. The similarity calculator uses WordNet, so is currently limited to the English language, but support for Hindi and French are planned for later in 2021. The comparison process runs as a background task and can take some time to complete. Once all the similarity values are known between all the learning objects, the learning object graph (LOG) can be made. A network graph is created where the nodes are the learning objects from the course and the similarity values between objects is used to position the nodes, grouping learning objects with similar content. This plugin can be used by itself to examine the similarity between learning activities and also integrates with the Behaviour Analytics plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ). The Behaviour Analytics plugin uses a network graph of learning objects to cluster students according to their behaviour patterns, but the graph nodes are grouped by section and require manual arrangement. The LORD plugin is designed to automatically configure the graph so that it does not have to be manually configured, which should produce better clustering.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: Sounds like a tough position you're in! - If your supervisor isn't giving you any support you may just need to look at a different project. To run the training of the analytics you will need a copy of a moodle database with a number of courses and historical logs - ideally the courses will have start and end dates set in the table already, however you can run some scripts that will set/guess the end-date of some of the courses. The "prediction" process currently requires active logs - or a way to generate user activity after the training process has been run (which is not all that easy to do on a testing site.) There is a research data set here which contains a logsstore and user data export, https://research.moodle.org/158/ But - it doesn't contain the course table in that data set which is needed for the analytics processes - you might be able to fake it by generating a bunch of courses that correspond to the courseid in the logstore table - if you're lucky it might even just be one course in that data-set but I haven't looked at using it myself. Depending on what your skillset is and how much time you have to work on this i have a number of "development" related ideas that would be good:

ResponsesInList.Title: New plugin Behaviour Analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings fellow Moodlers, The Behaviour Analytics block plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ) has recently been released in the Moodle plugin directory. This plugin provides teachers with a visualization of their students' learning behaviour patterns. Learning modules from a course are used as nodes in a network graph, which can be arbitrarily positioned. Student accesses to the modules create links between the nodes and become the students' behaviour pattern. It is possible to compare the learning patterns of students to see their similarities and differences for various time slices. The plugin also allows students to be clustered according to their behaviour patterns. Each student has a unique pattern that is compressed to a single point, then these student centroid points can be clustered to group students. Clusters of students may have common learning behaviours that can be viewed by hovering over a cluster centroid. It is also possible to annotate the students and clusters during the clustering stage. Currently, the VIP Research Group at Athabasca University ( https://vipresearchgroup.ca/ ) are also developing the LORD (learning Object Relation Discovery) Moodle plugin. The LORD plugin uses WordNet and Natural Language Processing to measure the similarity between two learning objects (activity modules). The similarities are used to automatically position the Learning Object Graph (LOG) nodes, rather than using manual positioning. Presently, only the English language is supported, but there are plans to support French and Hindi next year (2021). The LORD plugin has not yet been released to the Moodle plugin directory, but is available on GitHub ( https://github.com/Behaviour-Analytics/moodle-block_lord ). There is also a new version of Behaviour Analytics plugin available ( https://studyguide.athabascau.ca/networkgraph/download.php ) that is designed to integrate with LORD. Both LORD and the new Behaviour Analytics will get submitted to the Moodle plugin directory later this year.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New plugin Behaviour Analytics
ResponsesInList.Text: There are also some demonstration videos available: 1. How to use current released version of Behaviour Analytics: 2. How to use study ID and data set export features in new unreleased version of Behaviour Analytics: 3. How to use LORD and integrate LORD with Behaviour Analytics: use-and-integrate-lord.mp4

ResponsesInList.Text: We are a service provider that uses our moodle site as an LMS for company trainings.¬† Companies contract with us to provide online training to their employees.¬† The trainings are individual courses and companies are setup as Groups within each necessary course. Currently status reports need to be requested from us by the client, we use a custom SQL Report to pull a site-wide status report that uses the Institution user profile field as a filter. Has anyone needed or developed a report to use here?¬† I have a friend who does similar work, but not moodle, and he said the report would need to associate characteristics of the "report puller" to match to user fields, and that is the hurdle we would need to figure out first.¬† Looking forward to any assist someone may be able to add. Please let me know if additional information would help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom SQL Reporting Capability for Group Member Based on Group Membership
ResponsesInList.Text: Samantha, Your friend is on the right track. The Configurable Reports plugin has a number of variables including one for the user running the report and the current course, which allow it to do such things. A full list of such variables is available here. If you are using the standard user field of "institution", then with a simple restriction you can turn any query into one that matches some attribute of the person running the report: (some logic) JOIN prefix_user u (more logic) WHERE u.institution = (SELECT institution FROM prefix_user WHERE id = %%USERID%%) Something along those lines will give you what you need. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Contributed Ad-hoc not working
ResponsesInList.Text:
The issue is one of the peculiarities of the Ad-hoc report plugin: it will not accept the use of ? as the parameter inside regular text, which is used in the final SELECT statement in the CONCAT right before the FROM section to create the URL link to the badge itself using its hash. Instead, as the notes on the Ad-hoc page say, you need to replace the ? with either %%Q%% or with
a CHAR(63) which is the ASCII equivalent. The query works fine as is in Config Reports (or Adminer or phpMyAdmin , etc.) which does not have this oddity. You just need to make that substitution. See attachment for example. 
```text

```
